TEXT: Formerly Scholar of Trinity College, Cambridge

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: ARGUMENT

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: To Laius, King of Thebes, an oracle foretold that the child born to him

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: by his queen Jocasta would slay his father and wed his mother. So when

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: in time a son was born the infant’s feet were riveted together and he

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: was left to die on Mount Cithaeron. But a shepherd found the babe and

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: tended him, and delivered him to another shepherd who took him to his

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: master, the King of Corinth. Polybus being childless adopted the boy,

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: who grew up believing that he was indeed the King’s son. Afterwards

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: doubting his parentage he inquired of the Delphic god and heard himself

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: the word declared before to Laius. Wherefore he fled from what he

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: deemed his father’s house and in his flight he encountered and

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: unwillingly slew his father Laius. Arriving at Thebes he answered the

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: riddle of the Sphinx and the grateful Thebans made their deliverer

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: king. So he reigned in the room of Laius, and espoused the widowed

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: queen. Children were born to them and Thebes prospered under his rule,

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: but again a grievous plague fell upon the city. Again the oracle was

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: consulted and it bade them purge themselves of blood-guiltiness.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Oedipus denounces the crime of which he is unaware, and undertakes to

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: track out the criminal. Step by step it is brought home to him that he

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: is the man. The closing scene reveals Jocasta slain by her own hand and

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Oedipus blinded by his own act and praying for death or exile.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Oedipus.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Scene: Thebes. Before the Palace of Oedipus.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: OEDIPUS THE KING

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Suppliants of all ages are seated round the altar at the palace doors,

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: at their head a PRIEST OF ZEUS. To them enter OEDIPUS.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: My children, latest born to Cadmus old,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Why sit ye here as suppliants, in your hands

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Branches of olive filleted with wool?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: What means this reek of incense everywhere,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And everywhere laments and litanies?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Children, it were not meet that I should learn

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: From others, and am hither come, myself,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I Oedipus, your world-renowned king.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Ho! aged sire, whose venerable locks

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Proclaim thee spokesman of this company,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Explain your mood and purport. Is it dread

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Of ill that moves you or a boon ye crave?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: My zeal in your behalf ye cannot doubt;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Ruthless indeed were I and obdurate

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: If such petitioners as you I spurned.

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Yea, Oedipus, my sovereign lord and king,

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Thou seest how both extremes of age besiege

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Thy palace altars—fledglings hardly winged,

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: and greybeards bowed with years; priests, as am I

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: of Zeus, and these the flower of our youth.

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Meanwhile, the common folk, with wreathed boughs

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Crowd our two market-places, or before

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Both shrines of Pallas congregate, or where

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Ismenus gives his oracles by fire.

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: For, as thou seest thyself, our ship of State,

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Sore buffeted, can no more lift her head,

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Foundered beneath a weltering surge of blood.

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: A blight is on our harvest in the ear,

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: A blight upon the grazing flocks and herds,

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: A blight on wives in travail; and withal

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Armed with his blazing torch the God of Plague

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Hath swooped upon our city emptying

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: The house of Cadmus, and the murky realm

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Of Pluto is full fed with groans and tears.

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Therefore, O King, here at thy hearth we sit,

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: I and these children; not as deeming thee

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: A new divinity, but the first of men;

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: First in the common accidents of life,

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: And first in visitations of the Gods.

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Art thou not he who coming to the town

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: of Cadmus freed us from the tax we paid

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: To the fell songstress? Nor hadst thou received

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Prompting from us or been by others schooled;

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: No, by a god inspired (so all men deem,

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: And testify) didst thou renew our life.

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: And now, O Oedipus, our peerless king,

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: All we thy votaries beseech thee, find

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Some succor, whether by a voice from heaven

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Whispered, or haply known by human wit.

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Tried counselors, methinks, are aptest found1

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: To furnish for the future pregnant rede.

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Upraise, O chief of men, upraise our State!

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Look to thy laurels! for thy zeal of yore

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Our country’s savior thou art justly hailed:

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: O never may we thus record thy reign:—

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: “He raised us up only to cast us down.”

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Uplift us, build our city on a rock.

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Thy happy star ascendant brought us luck,

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: O let it not decline! If thou wouldst rule

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: This land, as now thou reignest, better sure

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: To rule a peopled than a desert realm.

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Nor battlements nor galleys aught avail,

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: If men to man and guards to guard them tail.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Ah! my poor children, known, ah, known too well,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The quest that brings you hither and your need.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Ye sicken all, well wot I, yet my pain,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: How great soever yours, outtops it all.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Your sorrow touches each man severally,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Him and none other, but I grieve at once

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Both for the general and myself and you.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Therefore ye rouse no sluggard from day-dreams.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Many, my children, are the tears I’ve wept,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And threaded many a maze of weary thought.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thus pondering one clue of hope I caught,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And tracked it up; I have sent Menoeceus’ son,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Creon, my consort’s brother, to inquire

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Of Pythian Phoebus at his Delphic shrine,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: How I might save the State by act or word.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And now I reckon up the tale of days

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Since he set forth, and marvel how he fares.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: ’Tis strange, this endless tarrying, passing strange.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: But when he comes, then I were base indeed,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: If I perform not all the god declares.

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Thy words are well timed; even as thou speakest

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: That shouting tells me Creon is at hand.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: O King Apollo! may his joyous looks

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Be presage of the joyous news he brings!

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: As I surmise, ’tis welcome; else his head

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Had scarce been crowned with berry-laden bays.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: We soon shall know; he’s now in earshot range.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: My royal cousin, say, Menoeceus’ child,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: What message hast thou brought us from the god?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Good news, for e’en intolerable ills,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Finding right issue, tend to naught but good.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: How runs the oracle? thus far thy words

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Give me no ground for confidence or fear.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: If thou wouldst hear my message publicly,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I’ll tell thee straight, or with thee pass within.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Speak before all; the burden that I bear

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Is more for these my subjects than myself.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Let me report then all the god declared.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: King Phoebus bids us straitly extirpate

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: A fell pollution that infests the land,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And no more harbor an inveterate sore.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: What expiation means he? What’s amiss?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Banishment, or the shedding blood for blood.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: This stain of blood makes shipwreck of our state.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Whom can he mean, the miscreant thus denounced?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Before thou didst assume the helm of State,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The sovereign of this land was Laius.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I heard as much, but never saw the man.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: He fell; and now the god’s command is plain:

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Punish his takers-off, whoe’er they be.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Where are they? Where in the wide world to find

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The far, faint traces of a bygone crime?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: In this land, said the god; “who seeks shall find;

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Who sits with folded hands or sleeps is blind.”

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Was he within his palace, or afield,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Or traveling, when Laius met his fate?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Abroad; he started, so he told us, bound

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: For Delphi, but he never thence returned.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Came there no news, no fellow-traveler

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: To give some clue that might be followed up?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: But one escape, who flying for dear life,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Could tell of all he saw but one thing sure.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And what was that? One clue might lead us far,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: With but a spark of hope to guide our quest.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Robbers, he told us, not one bandit but

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: A troop of knaves, attacked and murdered him.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Did any bandit dare so bold a stroke,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Unless indeed he were suborned from Thebes?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: So ’twas surmised, but none was found to avenge

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: His murder mid the trouble that ensued.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: What trouble can have hindered a full quest,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: When royalty had fallen thus miserably?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The riddling Sphinx compelled us to let slide

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The dim past and attend to instant needs.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Well, _I_ will start afresh and once again

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Make dark things clear. Right worthy the concern

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Of Phoebus, worthy thine too, for the dead;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I also, as is meet, will lend my aid

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: To avenge this wrong to Thebes and to the god.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Not for some far-off kinsman, but myself,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Shall I expel this poison in the blood;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: For whoso slew that king might have a mind

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: To strike me too with his assassin hand.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Therefore in righting him I serve myself.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Up, children, haste ye, quit these altar stairs,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Take hence your suppliant wands, go summon hither

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The Theban commons. With the god’s good help

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Success is sure; ’tis ruin if we fail.

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Come, children, let us hence; these gracious words

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Forestall the very purpose of our suit.

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: And may the god who sent this oracle

SPEAKER: PRIEST
TEXT: Save us withal and rid us of this pest.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Sweet-voiced daughter of Zeus from thy gold-paved Pythian shrine

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Wafted to Thebes divine,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: What dost thou bring me? My soul is racked and shivers with fear.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Hast thou some pain unknown before,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Or with the circling years renewest a penance of yore?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Offspring of golden Hope, thou voice immortal, O tell me.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: First on Athene I call; O Zeus-born goddess, defend!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Goddess and sister, befriend,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Artemis, Lady of Thebes, high-throned in the midst of our mart!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Lord of the death-winged dart!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Your threefold aid I crave

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: From death and ruin our city to save.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: If in the days of old when we nigh had perished, ye drave

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: From our land the fiery plague, be near us now and defend us!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Ah me, what countless woes are mine!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: All our host is in decline;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Weaponless my spirit lies.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Earth her gracious fruits denies;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Women wail in barren throes;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Life on life downstriken goes,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Swifter than the wind bird’s flight,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Swifter than the Fire-God’s might,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: To the westering shores of Night.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Wasted thus by death on death

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: All our city perisheth.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Corpses spread infection round;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: None to tend or mourn is found.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Wailing on the altar stair

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Wives and grandams rend the air—

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Long-drawn moans and piercing cries

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Blent with prayers and litanies.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Golden child of Zeus, O hear

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Let thine angel face appear!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: And grant that Ares whose hot breath I feel,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Though without targe or steel

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: He stalks, whose voice is as the battle shout,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: May turn in sudden rout,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: To the unharbored Thracian waters sped,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Or Amphitrite’s bed.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: For what night leaves undone,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Smit by the morrow’s sun

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Perisheth. Father Zeus, whose hand

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Doth wield the lightning brand,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Slay him beneath thy levin bold, we pray,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Slay him, O slay!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: O that thine arrows too, Lycean King,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: From that taut bow’s gold string,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Might fly abroad, the champions of our rights;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Yea, and the flashing lights

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Of Artemis, wherewith the huntress sweeps

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Across the Lycian steeps.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thee too I call with golden-snooded hair,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Whose name our land doth bear,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Bacchus to whom thy Maenads Evoe shout;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Come with thy bright torch, rout,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Blithe god whom we adore,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The god whom gods abhor.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Ye pray; ’tis well, but would ye hear my words

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And heed them and apply the remedy,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Ye might perchance find comfort and relief.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Mind you, I speak as one who comes a stranger

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: To this report, no less than to the crime;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: For how unaided could I track it far

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Without a clue? Which lacking (for too late

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Was I enrolled a citizen of Thebes)

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: This proclamation I address to all:—

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thebans, if any knows the man by whom

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Laius, son of Labdacus, was slain,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I summon him to make clean shrift to me.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And if he shrinks, let him reflect that thus

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Confessing he shall ’scape the capital charge;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: For the worst penalty that shall befall him

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Is banishment—unscathed he shall depart.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: But if an alien from a foreign land

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Be known to any as the murderer,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Let him who knows speak out, and he shall have

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Due recompense from me and thanks to boot.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: But if ye still keep silence, if through fear

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: For self or friends ye disregard my hest,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Hear what I then resolve; I lay my ban

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: On the assassin whosoe’er he be.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Let no man in this land, whereof I hold

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The sovereign rule, harbor or speak to him;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Give him no part in prayer or sacrifice

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Or lustral rites, but hound him from your homes.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: For this is our defilement, so the god

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Hath lately shown to me by oracles.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thus as their champion I maintain the cause

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Both of the god and of the murdered King.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And on the murderer this curse I lay

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Wretch, may he pine in utter wretchedness!

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And for myself, if with my privity

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: He gain admittance to my hearth, I pray

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The curse I laid on others fall on me.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: See that ye give effect to all my hest,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: For my sake and the god’s and for our land,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: A desert blasted by the wrath of heaven.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: For, let alone the god’s express command,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: It were a scandal ye should leave unpurged

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The murder of a great man and your king,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Nor track it home. And now that I am lord,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Successor to his throne, his bed, his wife,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Of issue, common children of one womb

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Had forced a closer bond twixt him and me,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: But Fate swooped down upon him), therefore I

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: His blood-avenger will maintain his cause

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: As though he were my sire, and leave no stone

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Unturned to track the assassin or avenge

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The son of Labdacus, of Polydore,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Of Cadmus, and Agenor first of the race.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And for the disobedient thus I pray:

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: May the gods send them neither timely fruits

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Of earth, nor teeming increase of the womb,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: But may they waste and pine, as now they waste,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Aye and worse stricken; but to all of you,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: My loyal subjects who approve my acts,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: May Justice, our ally, and all the gods

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Be gracious and attend you evermore.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The oath thou profferest, sire, I take and swear.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: I slew him not myself, nor can I name

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The slayer. For the quest, ’twere well, methinks

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: That Phoebus, who proposed the riddle, himself

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Should give the answer—who the murderer was.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Well argued; but no living man can hope

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: To force the gods to speak against their will.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: May I then say what seems next best to me?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Aye, if there be a third best, tell it too.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: My liege, if any man sees eye to eye

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: With our lord Phoebus, ’tis our prophet, lord

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Teiresias; he of all men best might guide

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: A searcher of this matter to the light.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Here too my zeal has nothing lagged, for twice

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: At Creon’s instance have I sent to fetch him,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And long I marvel why he is not here.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: I mind me too of rumors long ago—

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Mere gossip.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Tell them, I would fain know all.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: ’Twas said he fell by travelers.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: So I heard,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: But none has seen the man who saw him fall.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Well, if he knows what fear is, he will quail

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: And flee before the terror of thy curse.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Words scare not him who blenches not at deeds.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: But here is one to arraign him. Lo, at length

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: They bring the god-inspired seer in whom

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Above all other men is truth inborn.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Teiresias, seer who comprehendest all,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Lore of the wise and hidden mysteries,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: High things of heaven and low things of the earth,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thou knowest, though thy blinded eyes see naught,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: What plague infects our city; and we turn

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: To thee, O seer, our one defense and shield.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The purport of the answer that the God

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Returned to us who sought his oracle,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The messengers have doubtless told thee—how

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: One course alone could rid us of the pest,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: To find the murderers of Laius,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And slay them or expel them from the land.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Therefore begrudging neither augury

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Nor other divination that is thine,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: O save thyself, thy country, and thy king,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Save all from this defilement of blood shed.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: On thee we rest. This is man’s highest end,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: To others’ service all his powers to lend.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Alas, alas, what misery to be wise

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: When wisdom profits nothing! This old lore

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: I had forgotten; else I were not here.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: What ails thee? Why this melancholy mood?

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Let me go home; prevent me not; ’twere best

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: That thou shouldst bear thy burden and I mine.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: For shame! no true-born Theban patriot

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Would thus withhold the word of prophecy.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: _Thy_ words, O king, are wide of the mark, and I

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: For fear lest I too trip like thee...

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Oh speak,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Withhold not, I adjure thee, if thou know’st,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thy knowledge. We are all thy suppliants.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Aye, for ye all are witless, but my voice

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Will ne’er reveal my miseries—or thine.2

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: What then, thou knowest, and yet willst not speak!

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Wouldst thou betray us and destroy the State?

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: I will not vex myself nor thee. Why ask

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Thus idly what from me thou shalt not learn?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Monster! thy silence would incense a flint.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Will nothing loose thy tongue? Can nothing melt thee,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Or shake thy dogged taciturnity?

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Thou blam’st my mood and seest not thine own

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Wherewith thou art mated; no, thou taxest me.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And who could stay his choler when he heard

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: How insolently thou dost flout the State?

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Well, it will come what will, though I be mute.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Since come it must, thy duty is to tell me.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: I have no more to say; storm as thou willst,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: And give the rein to all thy pent-up rage.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Yea, I am wroth, and will not stint my words,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: But speak my whole mind. Thou methinks thou art he,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Who planned the crime, aye, and performed it too,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: All save the assassination; and if thou

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Hadst not been blind, I had been sworn to boot

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: That thou alone didst do the bloody deed.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Is it so? Then I charge thee to abide

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: By thine own proclamation; from this day

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Speak not to these or me. Thou art the man,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Thou the accursed polluter of this land.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Vile slanderer, thou blurtest forth these taunts,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And think’st forsooth as seer to go scot free.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Yea, I am free, strong in the strength of truth.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Who was thy teacher? not methinks thy art.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Thou, goading me against my will to speak.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: What speech? repeat it and resolve my doubt.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Didst miss my sense wouldst thou goad me on?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I but half caught thy meaning; say it again.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: I say thou art the murderer of the man

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Whose murderer thou pursuest.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thou shalt rue it

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Twice to repeat so gross a calumny.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Must I say more to aggravate thy rage?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Say all thou wilt; it will be but waste of breath.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: I say thou livest with thy nearest kin

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: In infamy, unwitting in thy shame.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Think’st thou for aye unscathed to wag thy tongue?

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Yea, if the might of truth can aught prevail.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: With other men, but not with thee, for thou

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: In ear, wit, eye, in everything art blind.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Poor fool to utter gibes at me which all

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Here present will cast back on thee ere long.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Offspring of endless Night, thou hast no power

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: O’er me or any man who sees the sun.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: No, for thy weird is not to fall by me.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: I leave to Apollo what concerns the god.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Is this a plot of Creon, or thine own?

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Not Creon, thou thyself art thine own bane.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: O wealth and empiry and skill by skill

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Outwitted in the battlefield of life,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: What spite and envy follow in your train!

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: See, for this crown the State conferred on me.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: A gift, a thing I sought not, for this crown

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The trusty Creon, my familiar friend,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Hath lain in wait to oust me and suborned

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: This mountebank, this juggling charlatan,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: This tricksy beggar-priest, for gain alone

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Keen-eyed, but in his proper art stone-blind.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Say, sirrah, hast thou ever proved thyself

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: A prophet? When the riddling Sphinx was here

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Why hadst thou no deliverance for this folk?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And yet the riddle was not to be solved

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: By guess-work but required the prophet’s art;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Wherein thou wast found lacking; neither birds

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Nor sign from heaven helped thee, but _I_ came,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The simple Oedipus; _I_ stopped her mouth

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: By mother wit, untaught of auguries.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: This is the man whom thou wouldst undermine,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: In hope to reign with Creon in my stead.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Methinks that thou and thine abettor soon

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Will rue your plot to drive the scapegoat out.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thank thy grey hairs that thou hast still to learn

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: What chastisement such arrogance deserves.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: To us it seems that both the seer and thou,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: O Oedipus, have spoken angry words.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: This is no time to wrangle but consult

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: How best we may fulfill the oracle.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: King as thou art, free speech at least is mine

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: To make reply; in this I am thy peer.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: I own no lord but Loxias; him I serve

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: And ne’er can stand enrolled as Creon’s man.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Thus then I answer: since thou hast not spared

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: To twit me with my blindness—thou hast eyes,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Yet see’st not in what misery thou art fallen,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Nor where thou dwellest nor with whom for mate.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Dost know thy lineage? Nay, thou know’st it not,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: And all unwitting art a double foe

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: To thine own kin, the living and the dead;

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Aye and the dogging curse of mother and sire

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: One day shall drive thee, like a two-edged sword,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Beyond our borders, and the eyes that now

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: See clear shall henceforward endless night.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Ah whither shall thy bitter cry not reach,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: What crag in all Cithaeron but shall then

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Reverberate thy wail, when thou hast found

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: With what a hymeneal thou wast borne

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Home, but to no fair haven, on the gale!

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Aye, and a flood of ills thou guessest not

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Shall set thyself and children in one line.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Flout then both Creon and my words, for none

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Of mortals shall be striken worse than thou.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Must I endure this fellow’s insolence?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: A murrain on thee! Get thee hence! Begone

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Avaunt! and never cross my threshold more.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: I ne’er had come hadst thou not bidden me.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I know not thou wouldst utter folly, else

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Long hadst thou waited to be summoned here.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Such am I—as it seems to thee a fool,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: But to the parents who begat thee, wise.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: What sayest thou—“parents”? Who begat me, speak?

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: This day shall be thy birth-day, and thy grave.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thou lov’st to speak in riddles and dark words.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: In reading riddles who so skilled as thou?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Twit me with that wherein my greatness lies.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: And yet this very greatness proved thy bane.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: No matter if I saved the commonwealth.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: ’Tis time I left thee. Come, boy, take me home.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Aye, take him quickly, for his presence irks

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And lets me; gone, thou canst not plague me more.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: I go, but first will tell thee why I came.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Thy frown I dread not, for thou canst not harm me.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Hear then: this man whom thou hast sought to arrest

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: With threats and warrants this long while, the wretch

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Who murdered Laius—that man is here.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: He passes for an alien in the land

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: But soon shall prove a Theban, native born.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: And yet his fortune brings him little joy;

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: For blind of seeing, clad in beggar’s weeds,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: For purple robes, and leaning on his staff,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: To a strange land he soon shall grope his way.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: And of the children, inmates of his home,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: He shall be proved the brother and the sire,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Of her who bare him son and husband both,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Co-partner, and assassin of his sire.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Go in and ponder this, and if thou find

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: That I have missed the mark, henceforth declare

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: I have no wit nor skill in prophecy.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Who is he by voice immortal named from Pythia’s rocky cell,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Doer of foul deeds of bloodshed, horrors that no tongue can tell?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: A foot for flight he needs

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Fleeter than storm-swift steeds,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: For on his heels doth follow,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Armed with the lightnings of his Sire, Apollo.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Like sleuth-hounds too

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The Fates pursue.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Yea, but now flashed forth the summons from Parnassus’ snowy peak,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: “Near and far the undiscovered doer of this murder seek!”

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Now like a sullen bull he roves

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Through forest brakes and upland groves,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: And vainly seeks to fly

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The doom that ever nigh

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Flits o’er his head,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Still by the avenging Phoebus sped,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The voice divine,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: From Earth’s mid shrine.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Sore perplexed am I by the words of the master seer.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Are they true, are they false? I know not and bridle my tongue for

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: fear,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Fluttered with vague surmise; nor present nor future is clear.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Quarrel of ancient date or in days still near know I none

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Twixt the Labdacidan house and our ruler, Polybus’ son.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Proof is there none: how then can I challenge our King’s good name,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: How in a blood-feud join for an untracked deed of shame?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: All wise are Zeus and Apollo, and nothing is hid from their ken;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: They are gods; and in wits a man may surpass his fellow men;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: But that a mortal seer knows more than I know—where

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Hath this been proven? Or how without sign assured, can I blame

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Him who saved our State when the winged songstress came,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Tested and tried in the light of us all, like gold assayed?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: How can I now assent when a crime is on Oedipus laid?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Friends, countrymen, I learn King Oedipus

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Hath laid against me a most grievous charge,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And come to you protesting. If he deems

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: That I have harmed or injured him in aught

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: By word or deed in this our present trouble,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I care not to prolong the span of life,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Thus ill-reputed; for the calumny

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Hits not a single blot, but blasts my name,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: If by the general voice I am denounced

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: False to the State and false by you my friends.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: This taunt, it well may be, was blurted out

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: In petulance, not spoken advisedly.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Did any dare pretend that it was I

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Prompted the seer to utter a forged charge?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Such things were said; with what intent I know not.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Were not his wits and vision all astray

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: When upon me he fixed this monstrous charge?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: I know not; to my sovereign’s acts I am blind.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: But lo, he comes to answer for himself.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Sirrah, what mak’st thou here? Dost thou presume

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: To approach my doors, thou brazen-faced rogue,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: My murderer and the filcher of my crown?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Come, answer this, didst thou detect in me

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Some touch of cowardice or witlessness,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: That made thee undertake this enterprise?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I seemed forsooth too simple to perceive

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The serpent stealing on me in the dark,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Or else too weak to scotch it when I saw.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: This _thou_ art witless seeking to possess

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Without a following or friends the crown,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: A prize that followers and wealth must win.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Attend me. Thou hast spoken, ’tis my turn

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: To make reply. Then having heard me, judge.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thou art glib of tongue, but I am slow to learn

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Of thee; I know too well thy venomous hate.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: First I would argue out this very point.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: O argue not that thou art not a rogue.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: If thou dost count a virtue stubbornness,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Unschooled by reason, thou art much astray.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: If thou dost hold a kinsman may be wronged,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And no pains follow, thou art much to seek.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Therein thou judgest rightly, but this wrong

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: That thou allegest—tell me what it is.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Didst thou or didst thou not advise that I

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Should call the priest?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Yes, and I stand to it.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Tell me how long is it since Laius...

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Since Laius...? I follow not thy drift.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: By violent hands was spirited away.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: In the dim past, a many years agone.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Did the same prophet then pursue his craft?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Yes, skilled as now and in no less repute.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Did he at that time ever glance at me?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Not to my knowledge, not when I was by.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: But was no search and inquisition made?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Surely full quest was made, but nothing learnt.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Why failed the seer to tell his story _then_?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I know not, and not knowing hold my tongue.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: This much thou knowest and canst surely tell.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: What’s mean’st thou? All I know I will declare.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: But for thy prompting never had the seer

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Ascribed to me the death of Laius.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: If so he thou knowest best; but I

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Would put thee to the question in my turn.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Question and prove me murderer if thou canst.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Then let me ask thee, didst thou wed my sister?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: A fact so plain I cannot well deny.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And as thy consort queen she shares the throne?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I grant her freely all her heart desires.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And with you twain I share the triple rule?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Yea, and it is that proves thee a false friend.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Not so, if thou wouldst reason with thyself,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: As I with myself. First, I bid thee think,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Would any mortal choose a troubled reign

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Of terrors rather than secure repose,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: If the same power were given him? As for me,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I have no natural craving for the name

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Of king, preferring to do kingly deeds,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And so thinks every sober-minded man.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Now all my needs are satisfied through thee,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And I have naught to fear; but were I king,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: My acts would oft run counter to my will.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: How could a title then have charms for me

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Above the sweets of boundless influence?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I am not so infatuate as to grasp

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The shadow when I hold the substance fast.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Now all men cry me Godspeed! wish me well,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And every suitor seeks to gain my ear,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: If he would hope to win a grace from thee.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Why should I leave the better, choose the worse?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: That were sheer madness, and I am not mad.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: No such ambition ever tempted me,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Nor would I have a share in such intrigue.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And if thou doubt me, first to Delphi go,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: There ascertain if my report was true

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Of the god’s answer; next investigate

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: If with the seer I plotted or conspired,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And if it prove so, sentence me to death,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Not by thy voice alone, but mine and thine.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: But O condemn me not, without appeal,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: On bare suspicion. ’Tis not right to adjudge

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Bad men at random good, or good men bad.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I would as lief a man should cast away

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The thing he counts most precious, his own life,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: As spurn a true friend. Thou wilt learn in time

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The truth, for time alone reveals the just;

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: A villain is detected in a day.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: To one who walketh warily his words

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Commend themselves; swift counsels are not sure.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: When with swift strides the stealthy plotter stalks

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I must be quick too with my counterplot.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: To wait his onset passively, for him

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Is sure success, for me assured defeat.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: What then’s thy will? To banish me the land?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I would not have thee banished, no, but dead,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: That men may mark the wages envy reaps.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I see thou wilt not yield, nor credit me.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Thou art not wise.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Wise for myself at least.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Why not for me too?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Why for such a knave?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Suppose thou lackest sense.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Yet kings must rule.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Not if they rule ill.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Oh my Thebans, hear him!

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Thy Thebans? am not I a Theban too?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Cease, princes; lo there comes, and none too soon,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Jocasta from the palace. Who so fit

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: As peacemaker to reconcile your feud?

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Misguided princes, why have ye upraised

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: This wordy wrangle? Are ye not ashamed,

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: While the whole land lies striken, thus to voice

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Your private injuries? Go in, my lord;

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Go home, my brother, and forebear to make

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: A public scandal of a petty grief.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: My royal sister, Oedipus, thy lord,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Hath bid me choose (O dread alternative!)

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: An outlaw’s exile or a felon’s death.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Yes, lady; I have caught him practicing

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Against my royal person his vile arts.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: May I ne’er speed but die accursed, if I

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: In any way am guilty of this charge.

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Believe him, I adjure thee, Oedipus,

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: First for his solemn oath’s sake, then for mine,

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: And for thine elders’ sake who wait on thee.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Hearken, King, reflect, we pray thee, but not stubborn but relent.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Say to what should I consent?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Respect a man whose probity and troth

TEXT: Are known to all and now confirmed by oath.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Dost know what grace thou cravest?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Yea, I know.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Declare it then and make thy meaning plain.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Brand not a friend whom babbling tongues assail;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Let not suspicion ’gainst his oath prevail.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Bethink you that in seeking this ye seek

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: In very sooth my death or banishment?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: No, by the leader of the host divine!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Witness, thou Sun, such thought was never mine,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Unblest, unfriended may I perish,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: If ever I such wish did cherish!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: But O my heart is desolate

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Musing on our striken State,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Doubly fall’n should discord grow

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Twixt you twain, to crown our woe.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Well, let him go, no matter what it cost me,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Or certain death or shameful banishment,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: For your sake I relent, not his; and him,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Where’er he be, my heart shall still abhor.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Thou art as sullen in thy yielding mood

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: As in thine anger thou wast truculent.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Such tempers justly plague themselves the most.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Leave me in peace and get thee gone.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I go,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: By thee misjudged, but justified by these.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Lady, lead indoors thy consort; wherefore longer here delay?

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Tell me first how rose the fray.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Rumors bred unjust suspicious and injustice rankles sore.

TEXT: Were both at fault?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Both.

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: What was the tale?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Ask me no more. The land is sore distressed;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: ’Twere better sleeping ills to leave at rest.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Strange counsel, friend! I know thou mean’st me well,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And yet would’st mitigate and blunt my zeal.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: King, I say it once again,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Witless were I proved, insane,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: If I lightly put away

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thee my country’s prop and stay,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Pilot who, in danger sought,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: To a quiet haven brought

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Our distracted State; and now

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Who can guide us right but thou?

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Let me too, I adjure thee, know, O king,

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: What cause has stirred this unrelenting wrath.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I will, for thou art more to me than these.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Lady, the cause is Creon and his plots.

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: But what provoked the quarrel? make this clear.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: He points me out as Laius’ murderer.

SPEAKER: JOCASTA

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: He is too cunning to commit himself,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And makes a mouthpiece of a knavish seer.

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Then thou mayest ease thy conscience on that score.

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Listen and I’ll convince thee that no man

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Hath scot or lot in the prophetic art.

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Here is the proof in brief. An oracle

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Once came to Laius (I will not say

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: ’Twas from the Delphic god himself, but from

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: His ministers) declaring he was doomed

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: To perish by the hand of his own son,

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: A child that should be born to him by me.

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Now Laius—so at least report affirmed—

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Was murdered on a day by highwaymen,

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: No natives, at a spot where three roads meet.

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: As for the child, it was but three days old,

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: When Laius, its ankles pierced and pinned

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Together, gave it to be cast away

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: By others on the trackless mountain side.

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: So then Apollo brought it not to pass

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: The child should be his father’s murderer,

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Or the dread terror find accomplishment,

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: And Laius be slain by his own son.

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Such was the prophet’s horoscope. O king,

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Regard it not. Whate’er the god deems fit

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: To search, himself unaided will reveal.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: What memories, what wild tumult of the soul

TEXT: Came o’er me, lady, as I heard thee speak!

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: What mean’st thou? What has shocked and startled thee?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Methought I heard thee say that Laius

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Was murdered at the meeting of three roads.

SPEAKER: JOCASTA

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS

SPEAKER: JOCASTA

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And how long is it since these things befell?

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: ’Twas but a brief while were thou wast proclaimed

SPEAKER: JOCASTA

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: O Zeus, what hast thou willed to do with me!

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: What is it, Oedipus, that moves thee so?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Ask me not yet; tell me the build and height

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Of Laius? Was he still in manhood’s prime?

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Tall was he, and his hair was lightly strewn

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: With silver; and not unlike thee in form.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: O woe is me! Mehtinks unwittingly

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I laid but now a dread curse on myself.

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: What say’st thou? When I look upon thee, my king,

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: I tremble.

TEXT: ’Tis a dread presentiment

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: That in the end the seer will prove not blind.

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: I quail; but ask, and I will answer all.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Had he but few attendants or a train

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Of armed retainers with him, like a prince?

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: They were but five in all, and one of them

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: A herald; Laius in a mule-car rode.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Alas! ’tis clear as noonday now. But say,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Lady, who carried this report to Thebes?

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: A serf, the sole survivor who returned.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Thee reigning in the stead of Laius slain,

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: He clasped my hand and supplicated me

TEXT: To send him to the alps and pastures, where

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: He might be farthest from the sight of Thebes.

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: And so I sent him. ’Twas an honest slave

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: And well deserved some better recompense.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Fetch him at once. I fain would see the man.

SPEAKER: JOCASTA

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Lady, I fear my tongue has overrun

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Discretion; therefore I would question him.

TEXT: Well, he shall come, but may not I too claim

SPEAKER: JOCASTA

TEXT: Who has a higher claim that thou to hear

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: My tale of dire adventures? Listen then.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: My sire was Polybus of Corinth, and

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: My mother Merope, a Dorian;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And I was held the foremost citizen,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS

TEXT: To comfort me, but still the venomed barb

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: A herald met me and a man who sat

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS

TEXT: Then jostled by the charioteer in wrath

TEXT: Am I not utterly unclean, a wretch

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: He dies in nature’s course, not by his hand.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: My wife, my queen, Jocasta, why hast thou

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Summoned me from my palace?

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Hear this man,

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: And as thou hearest judge what has become

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Of all those awe-inspiring oracles.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Who is this man, and what his news for me?

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: He comes from Corinth and his message this:

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Thy father Polybus hath passed away.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: What? let me have it, stranger, from thy mouth.

TEXT: If I must first make plain beyond a doubt

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: One touch will send an old man to his rest.

TEXT: So of some malady he died, poor man.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Yes, having measured the full span of years.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Out on it, lady! why should one regard

TEXT: The Pythian hearth or birds that scream i’ the air?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Did they not point at me as doomed to slay

TEXT: My father? but he’s dead and in his grave

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And here am I who ne’er unsheathed a sword;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Unless the longing for his absent son

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Killed him and so _I_ slew him in a sense.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: But, as they stand, the oracles are dead—

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Dust, ashes, nothing, dead as Polybus.

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Say, did not I foretell this long ago?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thou didst: but I was misled by my fear.

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Then let I no more weigh upon thy soul.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Must I not fear my mother’s marriage bed.

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Why should a mortal man, the sport of chance,

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: With no assured foreknowledge, be afraid?

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Best live a careless life from hand to mouth.

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: This wedlock with thy mother fear not thou.

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: How oft it chances that in dreams a man

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Has wed his mother! He who least regards

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Such brainsick phantasies lives most at ease.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I should have shared in full thy confidence,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Were not my mother living; since she lives

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Though half convinced I still must live in dread.

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: And yet thy sire’s death lights out darkness much.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Much, but my fear is touching her who lives.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Who may this woman be whom thus you fear?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Merope, stranger, wife of Polybus.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: And what of her can cause you any fear?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: A heaven-sent oracle of dread import.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: A mystery, or may a stranger hear it?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Aye, ’tis no secret. Loxias once foretold

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: That I should mate with mine own mother, and shed

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: With my own hands the blood of my own sire.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Hence Corinth was for many a year to me

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: A home distant; and I trove abroad,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: But missed the sweetest sight, my parents’ face.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Was this the fear that exiled thee from home?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Yea, and the dread of slaying my own sire.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Why, since I came to give thee pleasure, King,

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Have I not rid thee of this second fear?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Well, thou shalt have due guerdon for thy pains.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Well, I confess what chiefly made me come

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Was hope to profit by thy coming home.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS

SPEAKER: MESSENGER

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: If this is why thou dreadest to return.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Lest through thy parents thou shouldst be accursed?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: This and none other is my constant dread.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Dost thou not know thy fears are baseless all?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: How baseless, if I am their very son?

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Since Polybus was naught to thee in blood.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS

SPEAKER: MESSENGER

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS

SPEAKER: MESSENGER

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Know that he took thee from my hands, a gift.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: A childless man till then, he warmed to thee.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: I loosed the pin that riveted thy feet.

TEXT: Whence thou deriv’st the name that still is thine.

TEXT: Not I; another shepherd gave thee me.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: He passed indeed for one of Laius’ house.

TEXT: The king who ruled the country long ago?

TEXT: His fellow-countrymen should best know that.

TEXT: Methinks he means none other than the hind

TEXT: Our queen Jocasta best of all could tell.

TEXT: No, with such guiding clues I cannot fail

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: To bring to light the secret of my birth.

TEXT: Oh, as thou carest for thy life, give o’er

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: This quest. Enough the anguish _I_ endure.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Of a bondwoman, aye, through three descents

TEXT: I grow impatient of this best advice.

SPEAKER: JOCASTA
TEXT: Ah mayst thou ne’er discover who thou art!

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Go, fetch me here the herd, and leave yon woman

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: To glory in her pride of ancestry.

TEXT: I leave thee, henceforth silent evermore.

TEXT: Why, Oedipus, why stung with passionate grief

TEXT: Thinks scorn of my base parentage. But I

TEXT: Who rank myself as Fortune’s favorite child,

TEXT: Deeds I have suffered and myself have wrought;

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: Henceforward quenched in darkness shall ye see

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: Those ye should ne’er have seen; now blind to those

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: Whom, when I saw, I vainly yearned to know.”

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: Such was the burden of his moan, whereto,

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: Not once but oft, he struck with his hand uplift

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: His eyes, and at each stroke the ensanguined orbs

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: Bedewed his beard, not oozing drop by drop,

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: But one black gory downpour, thick as hail.

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: Such evils, issuing from the double source,

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: Have whelmed them both, confounding man and wife.

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: Till now the storied fortune of this house

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: Was fortunate indeed; but from this day

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: Woe, lamentation, ruin, death, disgrace,

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: All ills that can be named, all, all are theirs.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: But hath he still no respite from his pain?

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: He cries, “Unbar the doors and let all Thebes

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: Behold the slayer of his sire, his mother’s—”

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: That shameful word my lips may not repeat.

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: He vows to fly self-banished from the land,

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: Nor stay to bring upon his house the curse

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: Himself had uttered; but he has no strength

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: Nor one to guide him, and his torture’s more

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: Than man can suffer, as yourselves will see.

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: For lo, the palace portals are unbarred,

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: And soon ye shall behold a sight so sad

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: That he who must abhorred would pity it.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Woeful sight! more woeful none

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: These sad eyes have looked upon.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Whence this madness? None can tell

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Who did cast on thee his spell,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: prowling all thy life around,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Leaping with a demon bound.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Hapless wretch! how can I brook

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: On thy misery to look?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Though to gaze on thee I yearn,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Much to question, much to learn,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Horror-struck away I turn.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Ah me! ah woe is me!

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Ah whither am I borne!

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: How like a ghost forlorn

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: My voice flits from me on the air!

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: On, on the demon goads. The end, ah where?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: An end too dread to tell, too dark to see.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Dark, dark! The horror of darkness, like a shroud,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Wraps me and bears me on through mist and cloud.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Ah me, ah me! What spasms athwart me shoot,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: What pangs of agonizing memory?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: No marvel if in such a plight thou feel’st

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The double weight of past and present woes.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Ah friend, still loyal, constant still and kind,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thou carest for the blind.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I know thee near, and though bereft of eyes,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thy voice I recognize.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: O doer of dread deeds, how couldst thou mar

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thy vision thus? What demon goaded thee?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Apollo, friend, Apollo, he it was

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: That brought these ills to pass;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: But the right hand that dealt the blow

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Was mine, none other. How,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: How, could I longer see when sight

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Brought no delight?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Alas! ’tis as thou sayest.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Say, friends, can any look or voice

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Or touch of love henceforth my heart rejoice?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Haste, friends, no fond delay,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Take the twice cursed away

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Far from all ken,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The man abhorred of gods, accursed of men.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: O thy despair well suits thy desperate case.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Would I had never looked upon thy face!

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: My curse on him whoe’er unrived

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The waif’s fell fetters and my life revived!

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: He meant me well, yet had he left me there,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: He had saved my friends and me a world of care.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: I too had wished it so.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Then had I never come to shed

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: My father’s blood nor climbed my mother’s bed;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The monstrous offspring of a womb defiled,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Co-mate of him who gendered me, and child.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Was ever man before afflicted thus,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Like Oedipus.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: I cannot say that thou hast counseled well,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: For thou wert better dead than living blind.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: What’s done was well done. Thou canst never shake

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: My firm belief. A truce to argument.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: For, had I sight, I know not with what eyes

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I could have met my father in the shades,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Or my poor mother, since against the twain

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I sinned, a sin no gallows could atone.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Aye, but, ye say, the sight of children joys

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: A parent’s eyes. What, born as mine were born?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: No, such a sight could never bring me joy;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Nor this fair city with its battlements,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Its temples and the statues of its gods,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Sights from which I, now wretchedst of all,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Once ranked the foremost Theban in all Thebes,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: By my own sentence am cut off, condemned

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: By my own proclamation ’gainst the wretch,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The miscreant by heaven itself declared

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Unclean—and of the race of Laius.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thus branded as a felon by myself,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: How had I dared to look you in the face?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Nay, had I known a way to choke the springs

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Of hearing, I had never shrunk to make

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: A dungeon of this miserable frame,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Cut off from sight and hearing; for ’tis bliss

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: to bide in regions sorrow cannot reach.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Why didst thou harbor me, Cithaeron, why

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Didst thou not take and slay me? Then I never

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Had shown to men the secret of my birth.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: O Polybus, O Corinth, O my home,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Home of my ancestors (so wast thou called)

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: How fair a nursling then I seemed, how foul

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The canker that lay festering in the bud!

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Now is the blight revealed of root and fruit.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Ye triple high-roads, and thou hidden glen,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Coppice, and pass where meet the three-branched ways,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Ye drank my blood, the life-blood these hands spilt,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: My father’s; do ye call to mind perchance

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Those deeds of mine ye witnessed and the work

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I wrought thereafter when I came to Thebes?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: O fatal wedlock, thou didst give me birth,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And, having borne me, sowed again my seed,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Mingling the blood of fathers, brothers, children,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Brides, wives and mothers, an incestuous brood,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: All horrors that are wrought beneath the sun,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Horrors so foul to name them were unmeet.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: O, I adjure you, hide me anywhere

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Far from this land, or slay me straight, or cast me

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Down to the depths of ocean out of sight.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Come hither, deign to touch an abject wretch;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Draw near and fear not; I myself must bear

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The load of guilt that none but I can share.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Lo, here is Creon, the one man to grant

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Thy prayer by action or advice, for he

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Is left the State’s sole guardian in thy stead.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Ah me! what words to accost him can I find?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: What cause has he to trust me? In the past

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I have bee proved his rancorous enemy.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Not in derision, Oedipus, I come

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Nor to upbraid thee with thy past misdeeds.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: But shame upon you! if ye feel no sense

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Of human decencies, at least revere

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The Sun whose light beholds and nurtures all.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Leave not thus nakedly for all to gaze at

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: A horror neither earth nor rain from heaven

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Nor light will suffer. Lead him straight within,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: For it is seemly that a kinsman’s woes

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Be heard by kin and seen by kin alone.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: O listen, since thy presence comes to me

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: A shock of glad surprise—so noble thou,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And I so vile—O grant me one small boon.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I ask it not on my behalf, but thine.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And what the favor thou wouldst crave of me?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Forth from thy borders thrust me with all speed;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Set me within some vasty desert where

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: No mortal voice shall greet me any more.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: This had I done already, but I deemed

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: It first behooved me to consult the god.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: His will was set forth fully—to destroy

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The parricide, the scoundrel; and I am he.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Yea, so he spake, but in our present plight

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: ’Twere better to consult the god anew.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Dare ye inquire concerning such a wretch?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Yea, for thyself wouldst credit now his word.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Aye, and on thee in all humility

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I lay this charge: let her who lies within

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Receive such burial as thou shalt ordain;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Such rites ’tis thine, as brother, to perform.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: But for myself, O never let my Thebes,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The city of my sires, be doomed to bear

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The burden of my presence while I live.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: No, let me be a dweller on the hills,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: On yonder mount Cithaeron, famed as mine,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: My tomb predestined for me by my sire

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And mother, while they lived, that I may die

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Slain as they sought to slay me, when alive.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: This much I know full surely, nor disease

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Shall end my days, nor any common chance;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: For I had ne’er been snatched from death, unless

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I was predestined to some awful doom.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: So be it. I reck not how Fate deals with me

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: But my unhappy children—for my sons

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Be not concerned, O Creon, they are men,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And for themselves, where’er they be, can fend.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: But for my daughters twain, poor innocent maids,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Who ever sat beside me at the board

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Sharing my viands, drinking of my cup,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: For them, I pray thee, care, and, if thou willst,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: O might I feel their touch and make my moan.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Hear me, O prince, my noble-hearted prince!

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Could I but blindly touch them with my hands

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I’d think they still were mine, as when I saw.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: What say I? can it be my pretty ones

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Whose sobs I hear? Has Creon pitied me

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And sent me my two darlings? Can this be?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: ’Tis true; ’twas I procured thee this delight,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Knowing the joy they were to thee of old.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: God speed thee! and as meed for bringing them

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: May Providence deal with thee kindlier

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Than it has dealt with me! O children mine,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Where are ye? Let me clasp you with these hands,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: A brother’s hands, a father’s; hands that made

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Lack-luster sockets of his once bright eyes;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Hands of a man who blindly, recklessly,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Became your sire by her from whom he sprang.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Though I cannot behold you, I must weep

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: In thinking of the evil days to come,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The slights and wrongs that men will put upon you.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Where’er ye go to feast or festival,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: No merrymaking will it prove for you,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: But oft abashed in tears ye will return.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And when ye come to marriageable years,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Where’s the bold wooers who will jeopardize

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: To take unto himself such disrepute

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: As to my children’s children still must cling,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: For what of infamy is lacking here?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: “Their father slew his father, sowed the seed

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Where he himself was gendered, and begat

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: These maidens at the source wherefrom he sprang.”

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Such are the gibes that men will cast at you.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Who then will wed you? None, I ween, but ye

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Must pine, poor maids, in single barrenness.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: O Prince, Menoeceus’ son, to thee, I turn,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: With the it rests to father them, for we

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Their natural parents, both of us, are lost.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: O leave them not to wander poor, unwed,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thy kin, nor let them share my low estate.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: O pity them so young, and but for thee

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: All destitute. Thy hand upon it, Prince.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: To you, my children I had much to say,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Were ye but ripe to hear. Let this suffice:

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Pray ye may find some home and live content,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And may your lot prove happier than your sire’s.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Thou hast had enough of weeping; pass within.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I must obey,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Though ’tis grievous.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Weep not, everything must have its day.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Well I go, but on conditions.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: What thy terms for going, say.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Send me from the land an exile.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Ask this of the gods, not me.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: But I am the gods’ abhorrence.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Then they soon will grant thy plea.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Lead me hence, then, I am willing.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Come, but let thy children go.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Rob me not of these my children!

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Crave not mastery in all,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: For the mastery that raised thee was thy bane and wrought thy fall.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Look ye, countrymen and Thebans, this is Oedipus the great,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: He who knew the Sphinx’s riddle and was mightiest in our state.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Who of all our townsmen gazed not on his fame with envious eyes?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Now, in what a sea of troubles sunk and overwhelmed he lies!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Therefore wait to see life’s ending ere thou count one mortal blest;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Wait till free from pain and sorrow he has gained his final rest.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Formerly Scholar of Trinity College, Cambridge

SPEAKER: CHORUS

TEXT: Originally published by

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: ARGUMENT

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Oedipus, the blind and banished King of Thebes, has come in his

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: wanderings to Colonus, a deme of Athens, led by his daughter Antigone.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: He sits to rest on a rock just within a sacred grove of the Furies and

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: is bidden depart by a passing native. But Oedipus, instructed by an

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: oracle that he had reached his final resting-place, refuses to stir,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: and the stranger consents to go and consult the Elders of Colonus (the

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Chorus of the Play). Conducted to the spot they pity at first the blind

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: beggar and his daughter, but on learning his name they are

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: horror-striken and order him to quit the land. He appeals to the

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: world-famed hospitality of Athens and hints at the blessings that his

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: coming will confer on the State. They agree to await the decision of

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: King Theseus. From Theseus Oedipus craves protection in life and burial

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: in Attic soil; the benefits that will accrue shall be told later.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Theseus departs having promised to aid and befriend him. No sooner has

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: he gone than Creon enters with an armed guard who seize Antigone and

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: carry her off (Ismene, the other sister, they have already captured)

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: and he is about to lay hands on Oedipus, when Theseus, who has heard

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: the tumult, hurries up and, upbraiding Creon for his lawless act,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: threatens to detain him till he has shown where the captives are and

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: restored them. In the next scene Theseus returns bringing with him the

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: rescued maidens. He informs Oedipus that a stranger who has taken

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: sanctuary at the altar of Poseidon wishes to see him. It is Polyneices

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: who has come to crave his father’s forgiveness and blessing, knowing by

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: an oracle that victory will fall to the side that Oedipus espouses. But

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Oedipus spurns the hypocrite, and invokes a dire curse on both his

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: unnatural sons. A sudden clap of thunder is heard, and as peal follows

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: peal, Oedipus is aware that his hour is come and bids Antigone summon

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Theseus. Self-guided he leads the way to the spot where death should

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: overtake him, attended by Theseus and his daughters. Halfway he bids

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: his daughters farewell, and what followed none but Theseus knew. He was

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: not (so the Messenger reports) for the gods took him.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: DRAMATIS PERSONAE

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: OEDIPUS, banished King of Thebes.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: ANTIGONE, his daughter.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: ISMENE, his daughter.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: THESEUS, King of Athens.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: CREON, brother of Jocasta, now reigning at Thebes.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: POLYNEICES, elder son of Oedipus.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: STRANGER, a native of Colonus.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: MESSENGER, an attendant of Theseus.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: CHORUS, citizens of Colonus.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Scene: In front of the grove of the Eumenides.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: OEDIPUS AT COLONUS

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Enter the blind OEDIPUS led by his daughter, ANTIGONE.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Child of an old blind sire, Antigone,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: What region, say, whose city have we reached?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Who will provide today with scanted dole

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: This wanderer? ’Tis little that he craves,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And less obtains—that less enough for me;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: For I am taught by suffering to endure,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And the long years that have grown old with me,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And last not least, by true nobility.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: My daughter, if thou seest a resting place

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: On common ground or by some sacred grove,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Stay me and set me down. Let us discover

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Where we have come, for strangers must inquire

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Of denizens, and do as they are bid.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Long-suffering father, Oedipus, the towers

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: That fence the city still are faint and far;
