TEXT: And the Muses’ quire will never disdain

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: To visit this heaven-favored plain,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Nor the Cyprian queen of the golden rein.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: And here there grows, unpruned, untamed,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Terror to foemen’s spear,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: A tree in Asian soil unnamed,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: By Pelops’ Dorian isle unclaimed,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Self-nurtured year by year;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: ’Tis the grey-leaved olive that feeds our boys;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Nor youth nor withering age destroys

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The plant that the Olive Planter tends

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: And the Grey-eyed Goddess herself defends.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Yet another gift, of all gifts the most

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Prized by our fatherland, we boast—

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The might of the horse, the might of the sea;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Our fame, Poseidon, we owe to thee,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Son of Kronos, our king divine,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Who in these highways first didst fit

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: For the mouth of horses the iron bit;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thou too hast taught us to fashion meet

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: For the arm of the rower the oar-blade fleet,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Swift as the Nereids’ hundred feet

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: As they dance along the brine.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Oh land extolled above all lands, ’tis now

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: For thee to make these glorious titles good.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Why this appeal, my daughter?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Father, lo!

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Creon approaches with his company.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Fear not, it shall be so; if we are old,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: This country’s vigor has no touch of age.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Burghers, my noble friends, ye take alarm

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: At my approach (I read it in your eyes),

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Fear nothing and refrain from angry words.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I come with no ill purpose; I am old,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And know the city whither I am come,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Without a peer amongst the powers of Greece.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: It was by reason of my years that I

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Was chosen to persuade your guest and bring

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Him back to Thebes; not the delegate

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Of one man, but commissioned by the State,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Since of all Thebans I have most bewailed,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Being his kinsman, his most grievous woes.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: O listen to me, luckless Oedipus,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Come home! The whole Cadmeian people claim

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: With right to have thee back, I most of all,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: For most of all (else were I vile indeed)

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I mourn for thy misfortunes, seeing thee

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: An aged outcast, wandering on and on,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: A beggar with one handmaid for thy stay.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Ah! who had e’er imagined she could fall

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: To such a depth of misery as this,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: To tend in penury thy stricken frame,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: A virgin ripe for wedlock, but unwed,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: A prey for any wanton ravisher?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Seems it not cruel this reproach I cast

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: On thee and on myself and all the race?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Aye, but an open shame cannot be hid.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Hide it, O hide it, Oedipus, thou canst.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: O, by our fathers’ gods, consent I pray;

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Come back to Thebes, come to thy father’s home,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Bid Athens, as is meet, a fond farewell;

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Thebes thy old foster-mother claims thee first.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: O front of brass, thy subtle tongue would twist

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: To thy advantage every plea of right

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Why try thy arts on me, why spread again

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Toils where ’twould gall me sorest to be snared?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: In old days when by self-wrought woes distraught,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I yearned for exile as a glad release,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thy will refused the favor then I craved.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: But when my frenzied grief had spent its force,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And I was fain to taste the sweets of home,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Then thou wouldst thrust me from my country, then

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: These ties of kindred were by thee ignored;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And now again when thou behold’st this State

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And all its kindly people welcome me,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thou seek’st to part us, wrapping in soft words

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Hard thoughts. And yet what pleasure canst thou find

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: In forcing friendship on unwilling foes?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Suppose a man refused to grant some boon

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: When you importuned him, and afterwards

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: When you had got your heart’s desire, consented,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Granting a grace from which all grace had fled,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Would not such favor seem an empty boon?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Yet such the boon thou profferest now to me,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Fair in appearance, but when tested false.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Yea, I will proved thee false, that these may hear;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thou art come to take me, not to take me home,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: But plant me on thy borders, that thy State

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: May so escape annoyance from this land.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: _That_ thou shalt never gain, but _this_ instead—

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: My ghost to haunt thy country without end;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And for my sons, this heritage—no more—

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Just room to die in. Have not I more skill

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Than thou to draw the horoscope of Thebes?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Are not my teachers surer guides than thine—

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Great Phoebus and the sire of Phoebus, Zeus?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thou art a messenger suborned, thy tongue

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Is sharper than a sword’s edge, yet thy speech

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Will bring thee more defeats than victories.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Howbeit, I know I waste my words—begone,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And leave me here; whate’er may be my lot,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: He lives not ill who lives withal content.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Which loses in this parley, I o’erthrown

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: By thee, or thou who overthrow’st thyself?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I shall be well contented if thy suit

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Fails with these strangers, as it has with me.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Unhappy man, will years ne’er make thee wise?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Must thou live on to cast a slur on age?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thou hast a glib tongue, but no honest man,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Methinks, can argue well on any side.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: ’Tis one thing to speak much, another well.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thy words, forsooth, are few and all well aimed!

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Not for a man indeed with wits like thine.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Depart! I bid thee in these burghers’ name,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And prowl no longer round me to blockade

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: My destined harbor.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I protest to these,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Not thee, and for thine answer to thy kin,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: If e’er I take thee—

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Who against their will

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Could take me?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Though untaken thou shalt smart.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: What power hast thou to execute this threat?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: One of thy daughters is already seized,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The other I will carry off anon.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Woe, woe!

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: This is but prelude to thy woes.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Hast thou my child?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And soon shall have the other.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Ho, friends! ye will not surely play me false?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Chase this ungodly villain from your land.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Hence, stranger, hence avaunt! Thou doest wrong

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: In this, and wrong in all that thou hast done.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: CREON (to his guards).

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: ’Tis time by force to carry off the girl,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: If she refuse of her free will to go.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Ah, woe is me! where shall I fly, where find

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Succor from gods or men?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: What would’st thou, stranger?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I meddle not with him, but her who is mine.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: O princes of the land!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Sir, thou dost wrong.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Nay, right.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: How right?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I take but what is mine.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Help, Athens!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: What means this, sirrah? quick unhand her, or

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: We’ll fight it out.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Back!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Not till thou forbear.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: ’Tis war with Thebes if I am touched or harmed.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Did I not warn thee?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Quick, unhand the maid!

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Command your minions; I am not your slave.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Desist, I bid thee.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: CREON (to the guard)

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: And O bid thee march!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: To the rescue, one and all!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Rally, neighbors to my call!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: See, the foe is at the gate!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Rally to defend the State.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Ah, woe is me, they drag me hence, O friends.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Where art thou, daughter?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Haled along by force.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thy hands, my child!

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: They will not let me, father.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Away with her!

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Ah, woe is me, ah woe!

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: So those two crutches shall no longer serve thee

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: For further roaming. Since it pleaseth thee

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: To triumph o’er thy country and thy friends

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Who mandate, though a prince, I here discharge,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Enjoy thy triumph; soon or late thou’lt find

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Thou art an enemy to thyself, both now

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And in time past, when in despite of friends

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Thou gav’st the rein to passion, still thy bane.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Hold there, sir stranger!

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Hands off, have a care.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Restore the maidens, else thou goest not.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Then Thebes will take a dearer surety soon;

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I will lay hands on more than these two maids.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: What canst thou further?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Carry off this man.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Brave words!

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And deeds forthwith shall make them good.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Unless perchance our sovereign intervene.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: O shameless voice! Would’st lay an hand on me?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Silence, I bid thee!

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Goddesses, allow

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thy suppliant to utter yet one curse!

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Wretch, now my eyes are gone thou hast torn away

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The helpless maiden who was eyes to me;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: For these to thee and all thy cursed race

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: May the great Sun, whose eye is everywhere,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Grant length of days and old age like to mine.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Listen, O men of Athens, mark ye this?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: They mark us both and understand that I

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Wronged by the deeds defend myself with words.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Nothing shall curb my will; though I be old

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And single-handed, I will have this man.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: O woe is me!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thou art a bold man, stranger, if thou think’st

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: To execute thy purpose.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: So I do.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Then shall I deem this State no more a State.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: With a just quarrel weakness conquers might.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Ye hear his words?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Aye words, but not yet deeds,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Zeus knoweth!

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Zeus may haply know, not thou.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Insolence!

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Insolence that thou must bear.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Haste ye princes, sound the alarm!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Men of Athens, arm ye, arm!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Quickly to the rescue come

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Ere the robbers get them home.

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Why this outcry? What is forward? wherefore was I called away

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: From the altar of Poseidon, lord of your Colonus? Say!

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: On what errand have I hurried hither without stop or stay.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Dear friend—those accents tell me who thou art—

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Yon man but now hath done me a foul wrong.

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: What is this wrong and who hath wrought it? Speak.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Creon who stands before thee. He it is

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Hath robbed me of my all, my daughters twain.

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: What means this?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thou hast heard my tale of wrongs.

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Ho! hasten to the altars, one of you.

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Command my liegemen leave the sacrifice

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: And hurry, foot and horse, with rein unchecked,

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: To where the paths that packmen use diverge,

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Lest the two maidens slip away, and I

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Become a mockery to this my guest,

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: As one despoiled by force. Quick, as I bid.

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: As for this stranger, had I let my rage,

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Justly provoked, have play, he had not ’scaped

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Scathless and uncorrected at my hands.

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: But now the laws to which himself appealed,

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: These and none others shall adjudicate.

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Thou shalt not quit this land, till thou hast fetched

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: The maidens and produced them in my sight.

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Thou hast offended both against myself

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: And thine own race and country. Having come

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Unto a State that champions right and asks

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: For every action warranty of law,

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Thou hast set aside the custom of the land,

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: And like some freebooter art carrying off

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: What plunder pleases thee, as if forsooth

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Thou thoughtest this a city without men,

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Or manned by slaves, and me a thing of naught.

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Yet not from Thebes this villainy was learnt;

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Thebes is not wont to breed unrighteous sons,

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Nor would she praise thee, if she learnt that thou

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Wert robbing me—aye and the gods to boot,

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Haling by force their suppliants, poor maids.

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Were I on Theban soil, to prosecute

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: The justest claim imaginable, I

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Would never wrest by violence my own

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Without sanction of your State or King;

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: I should behave as fits an outlander

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Living amongst a foreign folk, but thou

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Shamest a city that deserves it not,

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Even thine own, and plentitude of years

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Have made of thee an old man and a fool.

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Therefore again I charge thee as before,

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: See that the maidens are restored at once,

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Unless thou would’st continue here by force

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: And not by choice a sojourner; so much

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: I tell thee home and what I say, I mean.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thy case is perilous; though by birth and race

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thou should’st be just, thou plainly doest wrong.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Not deeming this city void of men

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Or counsel, son of Aegeus, as thou say’st

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I did what I have done; rather I thought

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Your people were not like to set such store

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: by kin of mine and keep them ’gainst my will.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Nor would they harbor, so I stood assured,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: A godless parricide, a reprobate

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Convicted of incestuous marriage ties.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: For on her native hill of Ares here

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Sits Justice, and permits not vagrant folk

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: To stay within your borders. In that faith

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I hunted down my quarry; and e’en then

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I had refrained but for the curses dire

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Wherewith he banned my kinsfolk and myself:

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Such wrong, methought, had warrant for my act.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Anger has no old age but only death;

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The dead alone can feel no touch of spite.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: So thou must work thy will; my cause is just

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: But weak without allies; yet will I try,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Old as I am, to answer deeds with deeds.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: O shameless railer, think’st thou this abuse

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Defames my grey hairs rather than thine own?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Murder and incest, deeds of horror, all

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Thou blurtest forth against me, all I have borne,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: No willing sinner; so it pleased the gods

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Wrath haply with my sinful race of old,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Since thou could’st find no sin in me myself

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: For which in retribution I was doomed

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: To trespass thus against myself and mine.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Answer me now, if by some oracle

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: My sire was destined to a bloody end

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: By a son’s hand, can this reflect on me,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Me then unborn, begotten by no sire,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Conceived in no mother’s womb? And if

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: When born to misery, as born I was,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I met my sire, not knowing whom I met

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: or what I did, and slew him, how canst thou

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: With justice blame the all-unconscious hand?

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And for my mother, wretch, art not ashamed,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Seeing she was thy sister, to extort

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: From me the story of her marriage, such

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: A marriage as I straightway will proclaim.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: For I will speak; thy lewd and impious speech

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Has broken all the bonds of reticence.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: She was, ah woe is me! she was my mother;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I knew it not, nor she; and she my mother

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Bare children to the son whom she had borne,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: A birth of shame. But this at least I know

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Wittingly thou aspersest her and me;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: But I unwitting wed, unwilling speak.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Nay neither in this marriage or this deed

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Which thou art ever casting in my teeth—

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: A murdered sire—shall I be held to blame.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Come, answer me one question, if thou canst:

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: If one should presently attempt thy life,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Would’st thou, O man of justice, first inquire

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: If the assassin was perchance thy sire,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Or turn upon him? As thou lov’st thy life,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: On thy aggressor thou would’st turn, no stay

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Debating, if the law would bear thee out.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Such was my case, and such the pass whereto

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: The gods reduced me; and methinks my sire,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Could he come back to life, would not dissent.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Yet thou, for just thou art not, but a man

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Who sticks at nothing, if it serve his plea,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Reproachest me with this before these men.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: It serves thy turn to laud great Theseus’ name,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: And Athens as a wisely governed State;

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Yet in thy flatteries one thing is to seek:

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: If any land knows how to pay the gods

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Their proper rites, ’tis Athens most of all.

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: This is the land whence thou wast fain to steal

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: Their aged suppliant and hast carried off

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: My daughters. Therefore to yon goddesses,

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: I turn, adjure them and invoke their aid

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: To champion my cause, that thou mayest learn

SPEAKER: OEDIPUS
TEXT: What is the breed of men who guard this State.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: An honest man, my liege, one sore bestead

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: By fortune, and so worthy our support.

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Enough of words; the captors speed amain,

SPEAKER: THESEUS

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Why return?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: My soul is fain—

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Is fain?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: To see the earthy bed.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Sayest thou?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Where our sire is laid.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Nay, thou can’st not, dost not see—

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Sister, wherefore wroth with me?

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Know’st not—beside—

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: More must I hear?

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Tombless he died, none near.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Lead me thither; slay me there.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: How shall I unhappy fare,

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Friendless, helpless, how drag on

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: A life of misery alone?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Fear not, maids—

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Ah, whither flee?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Refuge hath been found.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: For me?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Where thou shalt be safe from harm.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: I know it.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Why then this alarm?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: How again to get us home

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: I know not.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Why then this roam?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Troubles whelm us—

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: As of yore.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Worse than what was worse before.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Sure ye are driven on the breakers’ surge.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Alas! we are.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Alas! ’tis so.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Ah whither turn, O Zeus? No ray

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Of hope to cheer the way

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Whereon the fates our desperate voyage urge.

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Dry your tears; when grace is shed

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: On the quick and on the dead

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: By dark Powers beneficent,

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Over-grief they would resent.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Aegeus’ child, to thee we pray.

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: What the boon, my children, say.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: With our own eyes we fain would see

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Our father’s tomb.

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: That may not be.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: What say’st thou, King?

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: My children, he

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Charged me straitly that no moral

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Should approach the sacred portal,

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Or greet with funeral litanies

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: The hidden tomb wherein he lies;

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Saying, “If thou keep’st my hest

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Thou shalt hold thy realm at rest.”

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: The God of Oaths this promise heard,

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: And to Zeus I pledged my word.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Well, if he would have it so,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: We must yield. Then let us go

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Back to Thebes, if yet we may

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Heal this mortal feud and stay

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: The self-wrought doom

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: That drives our brothers to their tomb.

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Go in peace; nor will I spare

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Ought of toil and zealous care,

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: But on all your needs attend,

SPEAKER: THESEUS
TEXT: Gladdening in his grave my friend.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Wail no more, let sorrow rest,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: All is ordered for the best.

SPEAKER: CHORUS

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: ARGUMENT

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Antigone, daughter of Oedipus, the late king of Thebes, in defiance of

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Creon who rules in his stead, resolves to bury her brother Polyneices,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: slain in his attack on Thebes. She is caught in the act by Creon’s

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: watchmen and brought before the king. She justifies her action,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: asserting that she was bound to obey the eternal laws of right and

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: wrong in spite of any human ordinance. Creon, unrelenting, condemns her

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: to be immured in a rock-hewn chamber. His son Haemon, to whom Antigone

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: is betrothed, pleads in vain for her life and threatens to die with

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: her. Warned by the seer Teiresias Creon repents him and hurries to

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: release Antigone from her rocky prison. But he is too late: he finds

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: lying side by side Antigone who had hanged herself and Haemon who also

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: has perished by his own hand. Returning to the palace he sees within

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: the dead body of his queen who on learning of her son’s death has

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: stabbed herself to the heart.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: DRAMATIS PERSONAE

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: ANTIGONE and ISMENE—daughters of Oedipus and sisters of Polyneices and

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Eteocles.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: CREON, King of Thebes.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: HAEMON, Son of Creon, betrothed to Antigone.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: EURYDICE, wife of Creon.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: TEIRESIAS, the prophet.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: CHORUS, of Theban elders.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: A WATCHMAN

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: A MESSENGER

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: A SECOND MESSENGER

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: ANTIGONE

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: ANTIGONE and ISMENE before the Palace gates.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Ismene, sister of my blood and heart,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: See’st thou how Zeus would in our lives fulfill

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: The weird of Oedipus, a world of woes!

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: For what of pain, affliction, outrage, shame,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Is lacking in our fortunes, thine and mine?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: And now this proclamation of today

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Made by our Captain-General to the State,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: What can its purport be? Didst hear and heed,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Or art thou deaf when friends are banned as foes?

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: To me, Antigone, no word of friends

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Has come, or glad or grievous, since we twain

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Were reft of our two brethren in one day

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: By double fratricide; and since i’ the night

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Our Argive leaguers fled, no later news

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Has reached me, to inspirit or deject.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: I know ’twas so, and therefore summoned thee

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Beyond the gates to breathe it in thine ear.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: What is it? Some dark secret stirs thy breast.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: What but the thought of our two brothers dead,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: The one by Creon graced with funeral rites,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: The other disappointed? Eteocles

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: He hath consigned to earth (as fame reports)

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: With obsequies that use and wont ordain,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: So gracing him among the dead below.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: But Polyneices, a dishonored corse,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: No man may bury him or make lament—

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Must leave him tombless and unwept, a feast

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: For kites to scent afar and swoop upon.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Such is the edict (if report speak true)

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Of Creon, our most noble Creon, aimed

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: At thee and me, aye me too; and anon

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: He will be here to promulgate, for such

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: As have not heard, his mandate; ’tis in sooth

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: No passing humor, for the edict says

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Whoe’er transgresses shall be stoned to death.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: So stands it with us; now ’tis thine to show

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: If thou art worthy of thy blood or base.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: But how, my rash, fond sister, in such case

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Can I do anything to make or mar?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Say, wilt thou aid me and abet? Decide.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: In what bold venture? What is in thy thought?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Lend me a hand to bear the corpse away.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: What, bury him despite the interdict?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: My brother, and, though thou deny him, thine

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: No man shall say that _I_ betrayed a brother.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Wilt thou persist, though Creon has forbid?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: What right has he to keep me from my own?

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Bethink thee, sister, of our father’s fate,

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Abhorred, dishonored, self-convinced of sin,

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Blinded, himself his executioner.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Think of his mother-wife (ill sorted names)

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Done by a noose herself had twined to death

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: And last, our hapless brethren in one day,

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Both in a mutual destiny involved,

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Self-slaughtered, both the slayer and the slain.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Bethink thee, sister, we are left alone;

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Shall we not perish wretchedest of all,

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: If in defiance of the law we cross

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: A monarch’s will?—weak women, think of that,

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Not framed by nature to contend with men.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Remember this too that the stronger rules;

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: We must obey his orders, these or worse.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Therefore I plead compulsion and entreat

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: The dead to pardon. I perforce obey

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: The powers that be. ’Tis foolishness, I ween,

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: To overstep in aught the golden mean.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: I urge no more; nay, wert thou willing still,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: I would not welcome such a fellowship.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Go thine own way; myself will bury him.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: How sweet to die in such employ, to rest,—

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Sister and brother linked in love’s embrace—

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: A sinless sinner, banned awhile on earth,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: But by the dead commended; and with them

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: I shall abide for ever. As for thee,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Scorn, if thou wilt, the eternal laws of Heaven.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: I scorn them not, but to defy the State

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Or break her ordinance I have no skill.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: A specious pretext. I will go alone

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: To lap my dearest brother in the grave.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: My poor, fond sister, how I fear for thee!

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: O waste no fears on me; look to thyself.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: At least let no man know of thine intent,

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: But keep it close and secret, as will I.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: O tell it, sister; I shall hate thee more

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: If thou proclaim it not to all the town.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Thou hast a fiery soul for numbing work.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: I pleasure those whom I would liefest please.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: If thou succeed; but thou art doomed to fail.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: When strength shall fail me, yes, but not before.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: But, if the venture’s hopeless, why essay?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Sister, forbear, or I shall hate thee soon,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: And the dead man will hate thee too, with cause.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Say I am mad and give my madness rein

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: To wreck itself; the worst that can befall

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Is but to die an honorable death.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Have thine own way then; ’tis a mad endeavor,

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Yet to thy lovers thou art dear as ever.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Sunbeam, of all that ever dawn upon

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Our seven-gated Thebes the brightest ray,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: O eye of golden day,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: How fair thy light o’er Dirce’s fountain shone,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Speeding upon their headlong homeward course,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Far quicker than they came, the Argive force;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Putting to flight

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The argent shields, the host with scutcheons white.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Against our land the proud invader came

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: To vindicate fell Polyneices’ claim.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Like to an eagle swooping low,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: On pinions white as new fall’n snow.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: With clanging scream, a horsetail plume his crest,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The aspiring lord of Argos onward pressed.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Hovering around our city walls he waits,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: His spearmen raven at our seven gates.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: But ere a torch our crown of towers could burn,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Ere they had tasted of our blood, they turn

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Forced by the Dragon; in their rear

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The din of Ares panic-struck they hear.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: For Zeus who hates the braggart’s boast

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Beheld that gold-bespangled host;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: As at the goal the paean they upraise,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: He struck them with his forked lightning blaze.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: To earthy from earth rebounding, down he crashed;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The fire-brand from his impious hand was dashed,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: As like a Bacchic reveler on he came,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Outbreathing hate and flame,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: And tottered. Elsewhere in the field,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Here, there, great Area like a war-horse wheeled;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Beneath his car down thrust

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Our foemen bit the dust.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Seven captains at our seven gates

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thundered; for each a champion waits,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Each left behind his armor bright,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Trophy for Zeus who turns the fight;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Save two alone, that ill-starred pair

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: One mother to one father bare,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Who lance in rest, one ’gainst the other

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Drave, and both perished, brother slain by brother.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Now Victory to Thebes returns again

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: And smiles upon her chariot-circled plain.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Now let feast and festal should

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Memories of war blot out.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Let us to the temples throng,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Dance and sing the live night long.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: God of Thebes, lead thou the round.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Bacchus, shaker of the ground!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Let us end our revels here;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Lo! Creon our new lord draws near,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Crowned by this strange chance, our king.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: What, I marvel, pondering?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Why this summons? Wherefore call

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Us, his elders, one and all,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Bidding us with him debate,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: On some grave concern of State?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Elders, the gods have righted one again

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Our storm-tossed ship of state, now safe in port.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: But you by special summons I convened

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: As my most trusted councilors; first, because

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I knew you loyal to Laius of old;

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Again, when Oedipus restored our State,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Both while he ruled and when his rule was o’er,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Ye still were constant to the royal line.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Now that his two sons perished in one day,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Brother by brother murderously slain,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: By right of kinship to the Princes dead,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I claim and hold the throne and sovereignty.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Yet ’tis no easy matter to discern

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The temper of a man, his mind and will,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Till he be proved by exercise of power;

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And in my case, if one who reigns supreme

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Swerve from the highest policy, tongue-tied

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: By fear of consequence, that man I hold,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And ever held, the basest of the base.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And I contemn the man who sets his friend

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Before his country. For myself, I call

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: To witness Zeus, whose eyes are everywhere,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: If I perceive some mischievous design

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: To sap the State, I will not hold my tongue;

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Nor would I reckon as my private friend

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: A public foe, well knowing that the State

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Is the good ship that holds our fortunes all:

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Farewell to friendship, if she suffers wreck.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Such is the policy by which I seek

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: To serve the Commons and conformably

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I have proclaimed an edict as concerns

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The sons of Oedipus; Eteocles

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Who in his country’s battle fought and fell,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The foremost champion—duly bury him

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: With all observances and ceremonies

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: That are the guerdon of the heroic dead.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: But for the miscreant exile who returned

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Minded in flames and ashes to blot out

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: His father’s city and his father’s gods,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And glut his vengeance with his kinsmen’s blood,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Or drag them captive at his chariot wheels—

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: For Polyneices ’tis ordained that none

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Shall give him burial or make mourn for him,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: But leave his corpse unburied, to be meat

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: For dogs and carrion crows, a ghastly sight.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: So am I purposed; never by my will

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Shall miscreants take precedence of true men,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: But all good patriots, alive or dead,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Shall be by me preferred and honored.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Son of Menoeceus, thus thou will’st to deal

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: With him who loathed and him who loved our State.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thy word is law; thou canst dispose of us

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The living, as thou will’st, as of the dead.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: See then ye execute what I ordain.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: On younger shoulders lay this grievous charge.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Fear not, I’ve posted guards to watch the corpse.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: What further duty would’st thou lay on us?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Not to connive at disobedience.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: No man is mad enough to court his death.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The penalty _is_ death: yet hope of gain

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Hath lured men to their ruin oftentimes.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: My lord, I will not make pretense to pant

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: And puff as some light-footed messenger.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: In sooth my soul beneath its pack of thought

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Made many a halt and turned and turned again;

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: For conscience plied her spur and curb by turns.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: “Why hurry headlong to thy fate, poor fool?”

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: She whispered. Then again, “If Creon learn

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: This from another, thou wilt rue it worse.”

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Thus leisurely I hastened on my road;

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Much thought extends a furlong to a league.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: But in the end the forward voice prevailed,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: To face thee. I will speak though I say nothing.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: For plucking courage from despair methought,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: ‘Let the worst hap, thou canst but meet thy fate.’

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: What is thy news? Why this despondency?

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Let me premise a word about myself?

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: I neither did the deed nor saw it done,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Nor were it just that I should come to harm.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Thou art good at parry, and canst fence about

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Some matter of grave import, as is plain.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: The bearer of dread tidings needs must quake.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Then, sirrah, shoot thy bolt and get thee gone.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Well, it must out; the corpse is buried; someone

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: E’en now besprinkled it with thirsty dust,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Performed the proper ritual—and was gone.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: What say’st thou? Who hath dared to do this thing?

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: I cannot tell, for there was ne’er a trace

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Of pick or mattock—hard unbroken ground,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Without a scratch or rut of chariot wheels,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: No sign that human hands had been at work.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: When the first sentry of the morning watch

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Gave the alarm, we all were terror-stricken.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: The corpse had vanished, not interred in earth,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: But strewn with dust, as if by one who sought

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: To avert the curse that haunts the unburied dead:

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Of hound or ravening jackal, not a sign.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Thereat arose an angry war of words;

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Guard railed at guard and blows were like to end it,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: For none was there to part us, each in turn

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Suspected, but the guilt brought home to none,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: From lack of evidence. We challenged each

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: The ordeal, or to handle red-hot iron,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Or pass through fire, affirming on our oath

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Our innocence—we neither did the deed

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Ourselves, nor know who did or compassed it.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Our quest was at a standstill, when one spake

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: And bowed us all to earth like quivering reeds,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: For there was no gainsaying him nor way

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: To escape perdition: _Ye_are_bound_to_tell_

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: _The_King,_ye_cannot_hide_it; so he spake.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: And he convinced us all; so lots were cast,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: And I, unlucky scapegoat, drew the prize.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: So here I am unwilling and withal

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Unwelcome; no man cares to hear ill news.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: I had misgivings from the first, my liege,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Of something more than natural at work.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: O cease, you vex me with your babblement;

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I am like to think you dote in your old age.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Is it not arrant folly to pretend

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: That gods would have a thought for this dead man?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Did they forsooth award him special grace,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And as some benefactor bury him,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Who came to fire their hallowed sanctuaries,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: To sack their shrines, to desolate their land,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And scout their ordinances? Or perchance

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The gods bestow their favors on the bad.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: No! no! I have long noted malcontents

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Who wagged their heads, and kicked against the yoke,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Misliking these my orders, and my rule.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: ’Tis they, I warrant, who suborned my guards

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: By bribes. Of evils current upon earth

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The worst is money. Money ’tis that sacks

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Cities, and drives men forth from hearth and home;

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Warps and seduces native innocence,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And breeds a habit of dishonesty.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: But they who sold themselves shall find their greed

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Out-shot the mark, and rue it soon or late.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Yea, as I still revere the dread of Zeus,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: By Zeus I swear, except ye find and bring

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Before my presence here the very man

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Who carried out this lawless burial,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Death for your punishment shall not suffice.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Hanged on a cross, alive ye first shall make

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Confession of this outrage. This will teach you

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: What practices are like to serve your turn.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: There are some villainies that bring no gain.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: For by dishonesty the few may thrive,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The many come to ruin and disgrace.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: May I not speak, or must I turn and go

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Without a word?—

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Begone! canst thou not see

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: That e’en this question irks me?

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Where, my lord?

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Is it thy ears that suffer, or thy heart?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Why seek to probe and find the seat of pain?

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: I gall thine ears—this miscreant thy mind.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: What an inveterate babbler! get thee gone!

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Babbler perchance, but innocent of the crime.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Twice guilty, having sold thy soul for gain.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Alas! how sad when reasoners reason wrong.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Go, quibble with thy reason. If thou fail’st

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: To find these malefactors, thou shalt own

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The wages of ill-gotten gains is death.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: I pray he may be found. But caught or not

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Shalt see me here returning; that is sure.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: For past all hope or thought I have escaped,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: And for my safety owe the gods much thanks.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Many wonders there be, but naught more wondrous than man;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Over the surging sea, with a whitening south wind wan,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Through the foam of the firth, man makes his perilous way;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: And the eldest of deities Earth that knows not toil nor decay

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Ever he furrows and scores, as his team, year in year out,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: With breed of the yoked horse, the ploughshare turneth about.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The light-witted birds of the air, the beasts of the weald and the wood

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: He traps with his woven snare, and the brood of the briny flood.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Master of cunning he: the savage bull, and the hart

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Who roams the mountain free, are tamed by his infinite art;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: And the shaggy rough-maned steed is broken to bear the bit.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Speech and the wind-swift speed of counsel and civic wit,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: He hath learnt for himself all these; and the arrowy rain to fly

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: And the nipping airs that freeze, ’neath the open winter sky.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: He hath provision for all: fell plague he hath learnt to endure;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Safe whate’er may befall: yet for death he hath found no cure.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Passing the wildest flight thought are the cunning and skill,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: That guide man now to the light, but now to counsels of ill.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: If he honors the laws of the land, and reveres the Gods of the State

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Proudly his city shall stand; but a cityless outcast I rate

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Whoso bold in his pride from the path of right doth depart;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Ne’er may I sit by his side, or share the thoughts of his heart.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: What strange vision meets my eyes,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Fills me with a wild surprise?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Sure I know her, sure ’tis she,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The maid Antigone.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Hapless child of hapless sire,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Didst thou recklessly conspire,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Madly brave the King’s decree?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Therefore are they haling thee?

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Here is the culprit taken in the act

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Of giving burial. But where’s the King?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: There from the palace he returns in time.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Why is my presence timely? What has chanced?

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: No man, my lord, should make a vow, for if

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: He ever swears he will not do a thing,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: His afterthoughts belie his first resolve.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: When from the hail-storm of thy threats I fled

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: I sware thou wouldst not see me here again;

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: But the wild rapture of a glad surprise

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Intoxicates, and so I’m here forsworn.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: And here’s my prisoner, caught in the very act,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Decking the grave. No lottery this time;

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: This prize is mine by right of treasure-trove.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: So take her, judge her, rack her, if thou wilt.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: She’s thine, my liege; but I may rightly claim

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Hence to depart well quit of all these ills.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Say, how didst thou arrest the maid, and where?

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Burying the man. There’s nothing more to tell.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Hast thou thy wits? Or know’st thou what thou say’st?

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: I saw this woman burying the corpse

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Against thy orders. Is that clear and plain?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: But how was she surprised and caught in the act?

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: It happened thus. No sooner had we come,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Driven from thy presence by those awful threats,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Than straight we swept away all trace of dust,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: And bared the clammy body. Then we sat

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: High on the ridge to windward of the stench,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: While each man kept he fellow alert and rated

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Roundly the sluggard if he chanced to nap.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: So all night long we watched, until the sun

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Stood high in heaven, and his blazing beams

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Smote us. A sudden whirlwind then upraised

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: A cloud of dust that blotted out the sky,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: And swept the plain, and stripped the woodlands bare,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: And shook the firmament. We closed our eyes

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: And waited till the heaven-sent plague should pass.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: At last it ceased, and lo! there stood this maid.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: A piercing cry she uttered, sad and shrill,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: As when the mother bird beholds her nest

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Robbed of its nestlings; even so the maid

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Wailed as she saw the body stripped and bare,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: And cursed the ruffians who had done this deed.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Anon she gathered handfuls of dry dust,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Then, holding high a well-wrought brazen urn,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Thrice on the dead she poured a lustral stream.

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: We at the sight swooped down on her and seized

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Our quarry. Undismayed she stood, and when

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: We taxed her with the former crime and this,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: She disowned nothing. I was glad—and grieved;

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: For ’tis most sweet to ’scape oneself scot-free,

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: And yet to bring disaster to a friend

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: Is grievous. Take it all in all, I deem

SPEAKER: GUARD
TEXT: A man’s first duty is to serve himself.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Speak, girl, with head bent low and downcast eyes,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Does thou plead guilty or deny the deed?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Guilty. I did it, I deny it not.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: CREON (to GUARD)

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Sirrah, begone whither thou wilt, and thank

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Thy luck that thou hast ’scaped a heavy charge.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Now answer this plain question, yes or no,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Wast thou acquainted with the interdict?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: I knew, all knew; how should I fail to know?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And yet wert bold enough to break the law?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Yea, for these laws were not ordained of Zeus,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: And she who sits enthroned with gods below,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Justice, enacted not these human laws.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Nor did I deem that thou, a mortal man,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Could’st by a breath annul and override

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: The immutable unwritten laws of Heaven.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: They were not born today nor yesterday;

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: They die not; and none knoweth whence they sprang.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: I was not like, who feared no mortal’s frown,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: To disobey these laws and so provoke

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: The wrath of Heaven. I knew that I must die,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: E’en hadst thou not proclaimed it; and if death

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Is thereby hastened, I shall count it gain.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: For death is gain to him whose life, like mine,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Is full of misery. Thus my lot appears

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Not sad, but blissful; for had I endured

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: To leave my mother’s son unburied there,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: I should have grieved with reason, but not now.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: And if in this thou judgest me a fool,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Methinks the judge of folly’s not acquit.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: A stubborn daughter of a stubborn sire,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: This ill-starred maiden kicks against the pricks.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Well, let her know the stubbornest of wills

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Are soonest bended, as the hardest iron,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: O’er-heated in the fire to brittleness,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Flies soonest into fragments, shivered through.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: A snaffle curbs the fieriest steed, and he

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Who in subjection lives must needs be meek.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: But this proud girl, in insolence well-schooled,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: First overstepped the established law, and then—

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: A second and worse act of insolence—

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: She boasts and glories in her wickedness.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Now if she thus can flout authority

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Unpunished, I am woman, she the man.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: But though she be my sister’s child or nearer

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Of kin than all who worship at my hearth,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Nor she nor yet her sister shall escape

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The utmost penalty, for both I hold,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: As arch-conspirators, of equal guilt.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Bring forth the older; even now I saw her

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Within the palace, frenzied and distraught.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The workings of the mind discover oft

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Dark deeds in darkness schemed, before the act.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: More hateful still the miscreant who seeks

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: When caught, to make a virtue of a crime.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Would’st thou do more than slay thy prisoner?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Not I, thy life is mine, and that’s enough.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Why dally then? To me no word of thine

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Is pleasant: God forbid it e’er should please;

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Nor am I more acceptable to thee.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: And yet how otherwise had I achieved

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: A name so glorious as by burying

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: A brother? so my townsmen all would say,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Where they not gagged by terror, Manifold

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: A king’s prerogatives, and not the least

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: That all his acts and all his words are law.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Of all these Thebans none so deems but thou.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: These think as I, but bate their breath to thee.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Hast thou no shame to differ from all these?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: To reverence kith and kin can bring no shame.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Was his dead foeman not thy kinsman too?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: One mother bare them and the self-same sire.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Why cast a slur on one by honoring one?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: The dead man will not bear thee out in this.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Surely, if good and evil fare alive.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: The slain man was no villain but a brother.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The patriot perished by the outlaw’s brand.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Nathless the realms below these rites require.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Not that the base should fare as do the brave.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Who knows if this world’s crimes are virtues there?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Not even death can make a foe a friend.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: My nature is for mutual love, not hate.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Die then, and love the dead if thou must;

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: No woman shall be the master while I live.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Lo from out the palace gate,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Weeping o’er her sister’s fate,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Comes Ismene; see her brow,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Once serene, beclouded now,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: See her beauteous face o’erspread

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: With a flush of angry red.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Woman, who like a viper unperceived

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Didst harbor in my house and drain my blood,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Two plagues I nurtured blindly, so it proved,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: To sap my throne. Say, didst thou too abet

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: This crime, or dost abjure all privity?

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: I did the deed, if she will have it so,

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: And with my sister claim to share the guilt.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: That were unjust. Thou would’st not act with me

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: At first, and I refused thy partnership.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: But now thy bark is stranded, I am bold

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: To claim my share as partner in the loss.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Who did the deed the under-world knows well:

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: A friend in word is never friend of mine.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: O sister, scorn me not, let me but share

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Thy work of piety, and with thee die.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Claim not a work in which thou hadst no hand;

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: One death sufficeth. Wherefore should’st thou die?

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: What would life profit me bereft of thee?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Ask Creon, he’s thy kinsman and best friend.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Why taunt me? Find’st thou pleasure in these gibes?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: ’Tis a sad mockery, if indeed I mock.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: O say if I can help thee even now.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: No, save thyself; I grudge not thy escape.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Is e’en this boon denied, to share thy lot?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Yea, for thou chosed’st life, and I to die.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Thou canst not say that I did not protest.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Well, some approved thy wisdom, others mine.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: But now we stand convicted, both alike.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Fear not; thou livest, I died long ago

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Then when I gave my life to save the dead.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Both maids, methinks, are crazed. One suddenly

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Has lost her wits, the other was born mad.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: Yea, so it falls, sire, when misfortune comes,

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: The wisest even lose their mother wit.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I’ faith thy wit forsook thee when thou mad’st

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Thy choice with evil-doers to do ill.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: What life for me without my sister here?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Say not thy sister _here_: thy sister’s dead.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: What, wilt thou slay thy own son’s plighted bride?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Aye, let him raise him seed from other fields.

SPEAKER: ISMENE
TEXT: No new espousal can be like the old.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: A plague on trulls who court and woo our sons.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: O Haemon, how thy sire dishonors thee!

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: A plague on thee and thy accursed bride!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: What, wilt thou rob thine own son of his bride?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: ’Tis death that bars this marriage, not his sire.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: So her death-warrant, it would seem, is sealed.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: By you, as first by me; off with them, guards,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And keep them close. Henceforward let them learn

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: To live as women use, not roam at large.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: For e’en the bravest spirits run away

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: When they perceive death pressing on life’s heels.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thrice blest are they who never tasted pain!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: If once the curse of Heaven attaint a race,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The infection lingers on and speeds apace,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Age after age, and each the cup must drain.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: So when Etesian blasts from Thrace downpour

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Sweep o’er the blackening main and whirl to land

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: From Ocean’s cavernous depths his ooze and sand,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Billow on billow thunders on the shore.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: On the Labdacidae I see descending

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Woe upon woe; from days of old some god

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Laid on the race a malison, and his rod

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Scourges each age with sorrows never ending.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The light that dawned upon its last born son

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Is vanished, and the bloody axe of Fate

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Has felled the goodly tree that blossomed late.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: O Oedipus, by reckless pride undone!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thy might, O Zeus, what mortal power can quell?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Not sleep that lays all else beneath its spell,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Nor moons that never tire: untouched by Time,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Throned in the dazzling light

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: That crowns Olympus’ height,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thou reignest King, omnipotent, sublime.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Past, present, and to be,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: All bow to thy decree,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: All that exceeds the mean by Fate

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Is punished, Love or Hate.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Hope flits about never-wearying wings;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Profit to some, to some light loves she brings,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: But no man knoweth how her gifts may turn,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Till ’neath his feet the treacherous ashes burn.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Sure ’twas a sage inspired that spake this word;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: _If evil good appear_

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: _To any, Fate is near_;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: And brief the respite from her flaming sword.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Hither comes in angry mood

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Haemon, latest of thy brood;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Is it for his bride he’s grieved,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Or her marriage-bed deceived,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Doth he make his mourn for thee,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Maid forlorn, Antigone?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Soon shall we know, better than seer can tell.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Learning may fixed decree anent thy bride,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Thou mean’st not, son, to rave against thy sire?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Know’st not whate’er we do is done in love?

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: O father, I am thine, and I will take

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Thy wisdom as the helm to steer withal.

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Therefore no wedlock shall by me be held

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: More precious than thy loving goverance.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Well spoken: so right-minded sons should feel,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: In all deferring to a father’s will.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: For ’tis the hope of parents they may rear

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: A brood of sons submissive, keen to avenge

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Their father’s wrongs, and count his friends their own.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: But who begets unprofitable sons,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: He verily breeds trouble for himself,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And for his foes much laughter. Son, be warned

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And let no woman fool away thy wits.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Ill fares the husband mated with a shrew,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And her embraces very soon wax cold.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: For what can wound so surely to the quick

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: As a false friend? So spue and cast her off,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Bid her go find a husband with the dead.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: For since I caught her openly rebelling,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Of all my subjects the one malcontent,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I will not prove a traitor to the State.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: She surely dies. Go, let her, if she will,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Appeal to Zeus the God of Kindred, for

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: If thus I nurse rebellion in my house,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Shall not I foster mutiny without?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: For whoso rules his household worthily,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Will prove in civic matters no less wise.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: But he who overbears the laws, or thinks

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: To overrule his rulers, such as one

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I never will allow. Whome’er the State

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Appoints must be obeyed in everything,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: But small and great, just and unjust alike.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I warrant such a one in either case

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Would shine, as King or subject; such a man

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Would in the storm of battle stand his ground,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: A comrade leal and true; but Anarchy—

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: What evils are not wrought by Anarchy!

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: She ruins States, and overthrows the home,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: She dissipates and routs the embattled host;

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: While discipline preserves the ordered ranks.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Therefore we must maintain authority

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And yield to title to a woman’s will.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Better, if needs be, men should cast us out

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Than hear it said, a woman proved his match.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: To me, unless old age have dulled wits,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thy words appear both reasonable and wise.

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Father, the gods implant in mortal men

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Reason, the choicest gift bestowed by heaven.

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: ’Tis not for me to say thou errest, nor

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Would I arraign thy wisdom, if I could;

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: And yet wise thoughts may come to other men

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: And, as thy son, it falls to me to mark

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: The acts, the words, the comments of the crowd.

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: The commons stand in terror of thy frown,

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: And dare not utter aught that might offend,

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: But I can overhear their muttered plaints,

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Know how the people mourn this maiden doomed

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: For noblest deeds to die the worst of deaths.

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: When her own brother slain in battle lay

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Unsepulchered, she suffered not his corse

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: To lie for carrion birds and dogs to maul:

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Should not her name (they cry) be writ in gold?

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Such the low murmurings that reach my ear.

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: O father, nothing is by me more prized

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Than thy well-being, for what higher good

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Can children covet than their sire’s fair fame,

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: As fathers too take pride in glorious sons?

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Therefore, my father, cling not to one mood,

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: And deemed not thou art right, all others wrong.

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: For whoso thinks that wisdom dwells with him,

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: That he alone can speak or think aright,

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Such oracles are empty breath when tried.

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: The wisest man will let himself be swayed

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: By others’ wisdom and relax in time.

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: See how the trees beside a stream in flood

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Save, if they yield to force, each spray unharmed,

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: But by resisting perish root and branch.

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: The mariner who keeps his mainsheet taut,

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: And will not slacken in the gale, is like

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: To sail with thwarts reversed, keel uppermost.

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Relent then and repent thee of thy wrath;

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: For, if one young in years may claim some sense,

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: I’ll say ’tis best of all to be endowed

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: With absolute wisdom; but, if that’s denied,

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Next wise is he who lists to sage advice.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: If he says aught in season, heed him, King.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Heed thou thy sire too; both have spoken well.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: What, would you have us at our age be schooled,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Lessoned in prudence by a beardless boy?

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: I plead for justice, father, nothing more.

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Weigh me upon my merit, not my years.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Strange merit this to sanction lawlessness!

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: For evil-doers I would urge no plea.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Is not this maid an arrant law-breaker?

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: The Theban commons with one voice say, No.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: What, shall the mob dictate my policy?

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: ’Tis thou, methinks, who speakest like a boy.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Am I to rule for others, or myself?

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: A State for one man is no State at all.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The State is his who rules it, so ’tis held.

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: As monarch of a desert thou wouldst shine.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: This boy, methinks, maintains the woman’s cause.

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: If thou be’st woman, yes. My thought’s for thee.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: O reprobate, would’st wrangle with thy sire?

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Because I see thee wrongfully perverse.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And am I wrong, if I maintain my rights?

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Talk not of rights; thou spurn’st the due of Heaven

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: O heart corrupt, a woman’s minion thou!

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Slave to dishonor thou wilt never find me.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Thy speech at least was all a plea for her.

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: And thee and me, and for the gods below.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Living the maid shall never be thy bride.

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: So she shall die, but one will die with her.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Hast come to such a pass as threaten me?

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: What threat is this, vain counsels to reprove?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Vain fool to instruct thy betters; thou shall rue it.

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Wert not my father, I had said thou err’st.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Play not the spaniel, thou a woman’s slave.

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: When thou dost speak, must no man make reply?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: This passes bounds. By heaven, thou shalt not rate

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And jeer and flout me with impunity.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Off with the hateful thing that she may die

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: At once, beside her bridegroom, in his sight.

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Think not that in my sight the maid shall die,

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Or by my side; never shalt thou again

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: Behold my face hereafter. Go, consort

SPEAKER: HAEMON
TEXT: With friends who like a madman for their mate.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thy son has gone, my liege, in angry haste.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Fell is the wrath of youth beneath a smart.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Let him go vent his fury like a fiend:

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: These sisters twain he shall not save from death.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Surely, thou meanest not to slay them both?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I stand corrected; only her who touched

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The body.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: And what death is she to die?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: She shall be taken to some desert place

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: By man untrod, and in a rock-hewn cave,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: With food no more than to avoid the taint

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: That homicide might bring on all the State,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Buried alive. There let her call in aid

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The King of Death, the one god she reveres,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Or learn too late a lesson learnt at last:

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: ’Tis labor lost, to reverence the dead.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Love resistless in fight, all yield at a glance of thine eye,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Love who pillowed all night on a maiden’s cheek dost lie,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Over the upland holds. Shall mortals not yield to thee?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Mad are thy subjects all, and even the wisest heart

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Straight to folly will fall, at a touch of thy poisoned dart.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thou didst kindle the strife, this feud of kinsman with kin,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: By the eyes of a winsome wife, and the yearning her heart to win.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: For as her consort still, enthroned with Justice above,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thou bendest man to thy will, O all invincible Love.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Lo I myself am borne aside,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: From Justice, as I view this bride.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Antigone, so young, so fair,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thus hurried down

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Death’s bower with the dead to share.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Friends, countrymen, my last farewell I make;

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: My journey’s done.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: One last fond, lingering, longing look I take

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: At the bright sun.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: For Death who puts to sleep both young and old

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Hales my young life,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: And beckons me to Acheron’s dark fold,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: An unwed wife.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: No youths have sung the marriage song for me,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: My bridal bed

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: No maids have strewn with flowers from the lea,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: ’Tis Death I wed.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: But bethink thee, thou art sped,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Great and glorious, to the dead.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thou the sword’s edge hast not tasted,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: No disease thy frame hath wasted.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Freely thou alone shalt go

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Living to the dead below.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Nay, but the piteous tale I’ve heard men tell

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Of Tantalus’ doomed child,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Chained upon Siphylus’ high rocky fell,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: That clung like ivy wild,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Drenched by the pelting rain and whirling snow,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Left there to pine,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: While on her frozen breast the tears aye flow—

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Her fate is mine.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: She was sprung of gods, divine,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Mortals we of mortal line.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Like renown with gods to gain

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Recompenses all thy pain.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Take this solace to thy tomb

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Hers in life and death thy doom.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Alack, alack! Ye mock me. Is it meet

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Thus to insult me living, to my face?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Cease, by our country’s altars I entreat,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Ye lordly rulers of a lordly race.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: O fount of Dirce, wood-embowered plain

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Where Theban chariots to victory speed,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Mark ye the cruel laws that now have wrought my bane,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: The friends who show no pity in my need!

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Was ever fate like mine? O monstrous doom,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Within a rock-built prison sepulchered,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: To fade and wither in a living tomb,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: And alien midst the living and the dead.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: In thy boldness over-rash

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Madly thou thy foot didst dash

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: ’Gainst high Justice’ altar stair.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thou a father’s guild dost bear.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: At this thou touchest my most poignant pain,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: My ill-starred father’s piteous disgrace,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: The taint of blood, the hereditary stain,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: That clings to all of Labdacus’ famed race.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Woe worth the monstrous marriage-bed where lay

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: A mother with the son her womb had borne,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Therein I was conceived, woe worth the day,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Fruit of incestuous sheets, a maid forlorn,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: And now I pass, accursed and unwed,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: To meet them as an alien there below;

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: And thee, O brother, in marriage ill-bestead,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: ’Twas thy dead hand that dealt me this death-blow.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Religion has her chains, ’tis true,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Let rite be paid when rites are due.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Yet is it ill to disobey

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The powers who hold by might the sway.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thou hast withstood authority,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: A self-willed rebel, thou must die.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Unwept, unwed, unfriended, hence I go,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: No longer may I see the day’s bright eye;

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Not one friend left to share my bitter woe,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: And o’er my ashes heave one passing sigh.

SPEAKER: CREON
