TEXT: If wail and lamentation aught availed

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: To stave off death, I trow they’d never end.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Away with her, and having walled her up

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: In a rock-vaulted tomb, as I ordained,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Leave her alone at liberty to die,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Or, if she choose, to live in solitude,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The tomb her dwelling. We in either case

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Are guiltless as concerns this maiden’s blood,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Only on earth no lodging shall she find.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: O grave, O bridal bower, O prison house

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Hewn from the rock, my everlasting home,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Whither I go to join the mighty host

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Of kinsfolk, Persephassa’s guests long dead,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: The last of all, of all more miserable,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: I pass, my destined span of years cut short.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: And yet good hope is mine that I shall find

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: A welcome from my sire, a welcome too,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: From thee, my mother, and my brother dear;

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: From with these hands, I laved and decked your limbs

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: In death, and poured libations on your grave.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: And last, my Polyneices, unto thee

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: I paid due rites, and this my recompense!

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Yet am I justified in wisdom’s eyes.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: For even had it been some child of mine,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Or husband mouldering in death’s decay,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: I had not wrought this deed despite the State.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: What is the law I call in aid? ’Tis thus

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: I argue. Had it been a husband dead

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: I might have wed another, and have borne

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Another child, to take the dead child’s place.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: But, now my sire and mother both are dead,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: No second brother can be born for me.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Thus by the law of conscience I was led

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: To honor thee, dear brother, and was judged

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: By Creon guilty of a heinous crime.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: And now he drags me like a criminal,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: A bride unwed, amerced of marriage-song

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: And marriage-bed and joys of motherhood,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: By friends deserted to a living grave.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: What ordinance of heaven have I transgressed?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Hereafter can I look to any god

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: For succor, call on any man for help?

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Alas, my piety is impious deemed.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Well, if such justice is approved of heaven,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: I shall be taught by suffering my sin;

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: But if the sin is theirs, O may they suffer

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: No worse ills than the wrongs they do to me.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The same ungovernable will

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Drives like a gale the maiden still.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Therefore, my guards who let her stay

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Shall smart full sore for their delay.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Ah, woe is me! This word I hear

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Brings death most near.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: I have no comfort. What he saith,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Portends no other thing than death.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: My fatherland, city of Thebes divine,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Ye gods of Thebes whence sprang my line,

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Look, puissant lords of Thebes, on me;

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: The last of all your royal house ye see.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Martyred by men of sin, undone.

SPEAKER: ANTIGONE
TEXT: Such meed my piety hath won.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Like to thee that maiden bright,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Danae, in her brass-bound tower,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Once exchanged the glad sunlight

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: For a cell, her bridal bower.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: And yet she sprang of royal line,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: My child, like thine,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: And nursed the seed

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: By her conceived

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Of Zeus descending in a golden shower.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Strange are the ways of Fate, her power

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Nor wealth, nor arms withstand, nor tower;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Nor brass-prowed ships, that breast the sea

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: From Fate can flee.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thus Dryas’ child, the rash Edonian King,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: For words of high disdain

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Did Bacchus to a rocky dungeon bring,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: To cool the madness of a fevered brain.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: His frenzy passed,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: He learnt at last

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: ’Twas madness gibes against a god to fling.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: For once he fain had quenched the Maenad’s fire;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: And of the tuneful Nine provoked the ire.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: By the Iron Rocks that guard the double main,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: On Bosporus’ lone strand,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Where stretcheth Salmydessus’ plain

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: In the wild Thracian land,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: There on his borders Ares witnessed

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The vengeance by a jealous step-dame ta’en

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The gore that trickled from a spindle red,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The sightless orbits of her step-sons twain.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Wasting away they mourned their piteous doom,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The blasted issue of their mother’s womb.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: But she her lineage could trace

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: To great Erecththeus’ race;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Daughter of Boreas in her sire’s vast caves

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Reared, where the tempest raves,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Swift as his horses o’er the hills she sped;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: A child of gods; yet she, my child, like thee,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: By Destiny

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: That knows not death nor age—she too was vanquished.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Princes of Thebes, two wayfarers as one,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Having betwixt us eyes for one, we are here.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: The blind man cannot move without a guide.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Why tidings, old Teiresias?

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: I will tell thee;

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: And when thou hearest thou must heed the seer.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Thus far I ne’er have disobeyed thy rede.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: So hast thou steered the ship of State aright.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I know it, and I gladly own my debt.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Bethink thee that thou treadest once again

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: The razor edge of peril.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: What is this?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Thy words inspire a dread presentiment.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: The divination of my arts shall tell.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Sitting upon my throne of augury,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: As is my wont, where every fowl of heaven

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Find harborage, upon mine ears was borne

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: A jargon strange of twitterings, hoots, and screams;

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: So knew I that each bird at the other tare

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: With bloody talons, for the whirr of wings

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Could signify naught else. Perturbed in soul,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: I straight essayed the sacrifice by fire

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: On blazing altars, but the God of Fire

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Came not in flame, and from the thigh bones dripped

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: And sputtered in the ashes a foul ooze;

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Gall-bladders cracked and spurted up: the fat

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Melted and fell and left the thigh bones bare.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Such are the signs, taught by this lad, I read—

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: As I guide others, so the boy guides me—

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: The frustrate signs of oracles grown dumb.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: O King, thy willful temper ails the State,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: For all our shrines and altars are profaned

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: By what has filled the maw of dogs and crows,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: The flesh of Oedipus’ unburied son.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Therefore the angry gods abominate

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Our litanies and our burnt offerings;

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Therefore no birds trill out a happy note,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Gorged with the carnival of human gore.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: O ponder this, my son. To err is common

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: To all men, but the man who having erred

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Hugs not his errors, but repents and seeks

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: The cure, is not a wastrel nor unwise.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: No fool, the saw goes, like the obstinate fool.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Let death disarm thy vengeance. O forbear

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: To vex the dead. What glory wilt thou win

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: By slaying twice the slain? I mean thee well;

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Counsel’s most welcome if I promise gain.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Old man, ye all let fly at me your shafts

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Like anchors at a target; yea, ye set

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Your soothsayer on me. Peddlers are ye all

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And I the merchandise ye buy and sell.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Go to, and make your profit where ye will,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Silver of Sardis change for gold of Ind;

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Ye will not purchase this man’s burial,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Not though the winged ministers of Zeus

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Should bear him in their talons to his throne;

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Not e’en in awe of prodigy so dire

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Would I permit his burial, for I know

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: No human soilure can assail the gods;

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: This too I know, Teiresias, dire’s the fall

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Of craft and cunning when it tries to gloss

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Foul treachery with fair words for filthy gain.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Alas! doth any know and lay to heart—

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Is this the prelude to some hackneyed saw?

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: How far good counsel is the best of goods?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: True, as unwisdom is the worst of ills.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Thou art infected with that ill thyself.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I will not bandy insults with thee, seer.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: And yet thou say’st my prophesies are frauds.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Prophets are all a money-getting tribe.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: And kings are all a lucre-loving race.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Dost know at whom thou glancest, me thy lord?

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Lord of the State and savior, thanks to me.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Skilled prophet art thou, but to wrong inclined.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Take heed, thou wilt provoke me to reveal

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: The mystery deep hidden in my breast.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Say on, but see it be not said for gain.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Such thou, methinks, till now hast judged my words.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Be sure thou wilt not traffic on my wits.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Know then for sure, the coursers of the sun

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Not many times shall run their race, before

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Thou shalt have given the fruit of thine own loins

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: In quittance of thy murder, life for life;

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: For that thou hast entombed a living soul,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: And sent below a denizen of earth,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: And wronged the nether gods by leaving here

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: A corpse unlaved, unwept, unsepulchered.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Herein thou hast no part, nor e’en the gods

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: In heaven; and thou usurp’st a power not thine.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: For this the avenging spirits of Heaven and Hell

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Who dog the steps of sin are on thy trail:

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: What these have suffered thou shalt suffer too.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: And now, consider whether bought by gold

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: I prophesy. For, yet a little while,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: And sound of lamentation shall be heard,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Of men and women through thy desolate halls;

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: And all thy neighbor States are leagues to avenge

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Their mangled warriors who have found a grave

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: I’ the maw of wolf or hound, or winged bird

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: That flying homewards taints their city’s air.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: These are the shafts, that like a bowman I

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Provoked to anger, loosen at thy breast,

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Unerring, and their smart thou shalt not shun.

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: Boy, lead me home, that he may vent his spleen

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: On younger men, and learn to curb his tongue

SPEAKER: TEIRESIAS
TEXT: With gentler manners than his present mood.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: My liege, that man hath gone, foretelling woe.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: And, O believe me, since these grizzled locks

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Were like the raven, never have I known

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The prophet’s warning to the State to fail.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I know it too, and it perplexes me.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: To yield is grievous, but the obstinate soul

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: That fights with Fate, is smitten grievously.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Son of Menoeceus, list to good advice.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: What should I do. Advise me. I will heed.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Go, free the maiden from her rocky cell;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: And for the unburied outlaw build a tomb.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Is that your counsel? You would have me yield?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Yea, king, this instant. Vengeance of the gods

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Is swift to overtake the impenitent.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Ah! what a wrench it is to sacrifice

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: My heart’s resolve; but Fate is ill to fight.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Go, trust not others. Do it quick thyself.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I go hot-foot. Bestir ye one and all,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: My henchmen! Get ye axes! Speed away

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: To yonder eminence! I too will go,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: For all my resolution this way sways.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: ’Twas I that bound, I too will set her free.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Almost I am persuaded it is best

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: To keep through life the law ordained of old.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thou by many names adored,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Child of Zeus the God of thunder,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Of a Theban bride the wonder,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Fair Italia’s guardian lord;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: In the deep-embosomed glades

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Of the Eleusinian Queen

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Haunt of revelers, men and maids,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Dionysus, thou art seen.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Where Ismenus rolls his waters,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Where the Dragon’s teeth were sown,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Where the Bacchanals thy daughters

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Round thee roam,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: There thy home;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thebes, O Bacchus, is thine own.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thee on the two-crested rock

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Lurid-flaming torches see;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Where Corisian maidens flock,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thee the springs of Castaly.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: By Nysa’s bastion ivy-clad,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: By shores with clustered vineyards glad,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: There to thee the hymn rings out,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: And through our streets we Thebans shout,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: All hall to thee

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Evoe, Evoe!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Oh, as thou lov’st this city best of all,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: To thee, and to thy Mother levin-stricken,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: In our dire need we call;

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thou see’st with what a plague our townsfolk sicken.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thy ready help we crave,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Whether adown Parnassian heights descending,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Or o’er the roaring straits thy swift was wending,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Save us, O save!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Brightest of all the orbs that breathe forth light,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Authentic son of Zeus, immortal king,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Leader of all the voices of the night,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Come, and thy train of Thyiads with thee bring,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thy maddened rout

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Who dance before thee all night long, and shout,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Thy handmaids we,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Evoe, Evoe!

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Attend all ye who dwell beside the halls

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Of Cadmus and Amphion. No man’s life

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: As of one tenor would I praise or blame,

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: For Fortune with a constant ebb and rise

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Casts down and raises high and low alike,

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: And none can read a mortal’s horoscope.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Take Creon; he, methought, if any man,

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Was enviable. He had saved this land

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Of Cadmus from our enemies and attained

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: A monarch’s powers and ruled the state supreme,

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: While a right noble issue crowned his bliss.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Now all is gone and wasted, for a life

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Without life’s joys I count a living death.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: You’ll tell me he has ample store of wealth,

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: The pomp and circumstance of kings; but if

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: These give no pleasure, all the rest I count

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: The shadow of a shade, nor would I weigh

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: His wealth and power ’gainst a dram of joy.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: What fresh woes bring’st thou to the royal house?

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Both dead, and they who live deserve to die.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Who is the slayer, who the victim? speak.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Haemon; his blood shed by no stranger hand.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: What mean ye? by his father’s or his own?

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: His own; in anger for his father’s crime.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: O prophet, what thou spakest comes to pass.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: So stands the case; now ’tis for you to act.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Lo! from the palace gates I see approaching

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Creon’s unhappy wife, Eurydice.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Comes she by chance or learning her son’s fate?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: EURYDICE

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Ye men of Thebes, I overheard your talk.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: As I passed out to offer up my prayer

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: To Pallas, and was drawing back the bar

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: To open wide the door, upon my ears

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: There broke a wail that told of household woe

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Stricken with terror in my handmaids’ arms

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: I fell and fainted. But repeat your tale

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: To one not unacquaint with misery.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Dear mistress, I was there and will relate

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: The perfect truth, omitting not one word.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Why should we gloze and flatter, to be proved

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Liars hereafter? Truth is ever best.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Well, in attendance on my liege, your lord,

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: I crossed the plain to its utmost margin, where

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: The corse of Polyneices, gnawn and mauled,

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Was lying yet. We offered first a prayer

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: To Pluto and the goddess of cross-ways,

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: With contrite hearts, to deprecate their ire.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Then laved with lustral waves the mangled corse,

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Laid it on fresh-lopped branches, lit a pyre,

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: And to his memory piled a mighty mound

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Of mother earth. Then to the caverned rock,

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: The bridal chamber of the maid and Death,

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: We sped, about to enter. But a guard

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Heard from that godless shrine a far shrill wail,

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: And ran back to our lord to tell the news.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: But as he nearer drew a hollow sound

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Of lamentation to the King was borne.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: He groaned and uttered then this bitter plaint:

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: “Am I a prophet? miserable me!

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Is this the saddest path I ever trod?

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: ’Tis my son’s voice that calls me. On press on,

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: My henchmen, haste with double speed to the tomb

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Where rocks down-torn have made a gap, look in

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: And tell me if in truth I recognize

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: The voice of Haemon or am heaven-deceived.”

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: So at the bidding of our distraught lord

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: We looked, and in the craven’s vaulted gloom

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: I saw the maiden lying strangled there,

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: A noose of linen twined about her neck;

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: And hard beside her, clasping her cold form,

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Her lover lay bewailing his dead bride

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Death-wedded, and his father’s cruelty.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: When the King saw him, with a terrible groan

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: He moved towards him, crying, “O my son

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: What hast thou done? What ailed thee? What mischance

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Has reft thee of thy reason? O come forth,

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Come forth, my son; thy father supplicates.”

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: But the son glared at him with tiger eyes,

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Spat in his face, and then, without a word,

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Drew his two-hilted sword and smote, but missed

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: His father flying backwards. Then the boy,

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Wroth with himself, poor wretch, incontinent

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Fell on his sword and drove it through his side

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Home, but yet breathing clasped in his lax arms

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: The maid, her pallid cheek incarnadined

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: With his expiring gasps. So there they lay

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Two corpses, one in death. His marriage rites

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Are consummated in the halls of Death:

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: A witness that of ills whate’er befall

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Mortals’ unwisdom is the worst of all.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: What makest thou of this? The Queen has gone

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Without a word importing good or ill.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: I marvel too, but entertain good hope.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: ’Tis that she shrinks in public to lament

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Her son’s sad ending, and in privacy

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Would with her maidens mourn a private loss.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Trust me, she is discreet and will not err.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: I know not, but strained silence, so I deem,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Is no less ominous than excessive grief.

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Well, let us to the house and solve our doubts,

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Whether the tumult of her heart conceals

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Some fell design. It may be thou art right:

SPEAKER: MESSENGER
TEXT: Unnatural silence signifies no good.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Lo! the King himself appears.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Evidence he with him bears

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: ’Gainst himself (ah me! I quake

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: ’Gainst a king such charge to make)

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: But all must own,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: The guilt is his and his alone.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Woe for sin of minds perverse,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Deadly fraught with mortal curse.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Behold us slain and slayers, all akin.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Woe for my counsel dire, conceived in sin.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Alas, my son,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Life scarce begun,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Thou wast undone.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: The fault was mine, mine only, O my son!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Too late thou seemest to perceive the truth.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: By sorrow schooled. Heavy the hand of God,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Thorny and rough the paths my feet have trod,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Humbled my pride, my pleasure turned to pain;

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Poor mortals, how we labor all in vain!

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: Sorrows are thine, my lord, and more to come,

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: One lying at thy feet, another yet

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: More grievous waits thee, when thou comest home.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: What woe is lacking to my tale of woes?

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: Thy wife, the mother of thy dead son here,

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: Lies stricken by a fresh inflicted blow.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: How bottomless the pit!

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Does claim me too, O Death?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: What is this word he saith,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: This woeful messenger? Say, is it fit

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: To slay anew a man already slain?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Is Death at work again,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Stroke upon stroke, first son, then mother slain?

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Look for thyself. She lies for all to view.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Alas! another added woe I see.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: What more remains to crown my agony?

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: A minute past I clasped a lifeless son,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And now another victim Death hath won.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Unhappy mother, most unhappy son!

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: Beside the altar on a keen-edged sword

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: She fell and closed her eyes in night, but erst

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: She mourned for Megareus who nobly died

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: Long since, then for her son; with her last breath

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: She cursed thee, the slayer of her child.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I shudder with affright

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: O for a two-edged sword to slay outright

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: A wretch like me,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Made one with misery.

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: ’Tis true that thou wert charged by the dead Queen

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: As author of both deaths, hers and her son’s.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: In what wise was her self-destruction wrought?

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: Hearing the loud lament above her son

SPEAKER: SECOND MESSENGER
TEXT: With her own hand she stabbed herself to the heart.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I am the guilty cause. I did the deed,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Thy murderer. Yea, I guilty plead.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: My henchmen, lead me hence, away, away,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: A cipher, less than nothing; no delay!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Well said, if in disaster aught is well

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: His past endure demand the speediest cure.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Come, Fate, a friend at need,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Come with all speed!

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Come, my best friend,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And speed my end!

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Away, away!

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Let me not look upon another day!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: This for the morrow; to us are present needs

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: That they whom it concerns must take in hand.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: I join your prayer that echoes my desire.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: O pray not, prayers are idle; from the doom

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Of fate for mortals refuge is there none.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Away with me, a worthless wretch who slew

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Unwitting thee, my son, thy mother too.

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Whither to turn I know now; every way

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Leads but astray,

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: And on my head I feel the heavy weight

SPEAKER: CREON
TEXT: Of crushing Fate.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Of happiness the chiefest part

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Is a wise heart:

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: And to defraud the gods in aught

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: With peril’s fraught.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Swelling words of high-flown might

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Mightily the gods do smite.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Chastisement for errors past

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Wisdom brings to age at last.
